headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Sean, I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Q4 2015 PulteGroup, Inc. Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Jim Zeumer, you may begin your conference.
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Sean, I'll be your conference operator today. At this time, I'd like to welcome everyone to the Q4 2015 PulteGroup, Inc. Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Mr. Jim Zeumer, you may begin your conference.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sean, and good morning to everyone participating in the conference call to discuss PulteGroup's fourth quarter financial results for the 3 months ended December 31, 2015.Joining me for today's call are Richard Dugas, Chairman, President, CEO;
componenttext:
Thank you, Sean, and good morning to everyone participating in the conference call to discuss PulteGroup's fourth quarter financial results for the 3 months ended December 31, 2015.
Joining me for today's call are Richard Dugas, Chairman, President, CEO; Bob O'Shaughnessy, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Jim Ossowski, Vice President, Finance and Controller.
A copy of this morning's earnings release and the presentation slides that accompanies today's discussion are posted to our corporate website at pultegroupinc.com. We will also post an audio replay of today's call to the site later on.
Let me remind all participants that today's presentation may include forward-looking statements about PulteGroup's future performance. Actual results could differ materially from those suggested by any comments made today. The most significant risk factors that could affect future results are summarized as part of today's earnings release and within the accompanying presentation slides. These risk factors and other key information are detailed in our SEC filings, including our annual and quarterly reports.
With that said, let me turn the call over to Richard Dugas. Richard?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm extremely pleased with PulteGroup's fourth quarter earnings, which showed significantly improved results across key business metrics. In addition to ending 2015 with very strong results, our fourth quarter operating and financial performance provided
componenttext:
I'm extremely pleased with PulteGroup's fourth quarter earnings, which showed significantly improved results across key business metrics. In addition to ending 2015 with very strong results, our fourth quarter operating and financial performance provided a foundation we can build on in 2016 as we capitalize on opportunities to accelerate the growth of our homebuilding business. 
Bob will go through a detailed review of our Q4 financials in a moment but there are a couple of numbers and points that I'd like to highlight. Order rates in the fourth quarter were up 13%, which is the biggest year-over-year percentage jump we have realized since 2012. As solid as this number is, what I view even more encouraging is the 9% gain and absorption pace that we realized in the quarter. We've always said that generating higher sales within our existing footprint is the most efficient way for us to grow volumes and ultimately, earnings. Pulte's disciplined approach to acquiring the right land positions over the past several years is having a positive impact on our results. 
Along with order rates, the average sales price we were able to realize for or comes continue to increase. In the fourth quarter, closing ASPs were up 6% to $353,000, while backlog ASPs gained 10% to $365,000. 
Between market opportunities, mixed shifts and ongoing implementation of our strategic pricing programs, we expect ASPs will continue to move higher in 2016 versus comparable quarters in 2015. Our recently closed purchase of assets from John Wieland Homes and Neighborhoods will further our pricing gains given their higher price points. 
I also want to highlight our gross margins, which at 23.5%, is up 40 basis points over last year and remains arguably among the highest in our industry. 
As we have discussed for the past several years, we've implemented a number of programs from product and purchasing zones and commonly managed plans to shoot [ph] cost and strategic pricing. As an example, almost 60% of our fourth quarter closes were from commonly managed plans that have the benefit of increased consumer feedback and more efficient floorplan design. 
The goal of all this work has been to improve sales paces and gross margins in support of delivering higher returns on invested capital. A lot of time and effort has been invested in implementing these initiatives and the gains are evident in our results. 
Given that the financial improvements we realized in the quarter were so broad-based, I could highlight a number of other metrics in my comments. I purposely picked order rates, ASPs and gross margin, because there is at least one common element, which I believe has been an important factor in all 3 metrics. That common element is land. 
In 2011, we launched a Value Creation strategy with is focused on delivering higher returns on invested capital over the housing cycle. By 2013, we had raised returns to the point where they exceeded our cost of capital. Since that time, we have purposely increased investment into the business because it makes economic sense to do so. While we have raised investment, we have done so while adhering to the guidelines and disciplines we put in place back in 2011. These disciplines include: Underwriting projects through a defined 13-point risk-weighting scorecard that helps ensure we select the highest-returning projects, focusing on land positions that are closer in to job centers and located in the better markets and submarkets, prudently using options, which now account for 31% of all lots and 34% of our more traditional Pulte and Centex land positions to help enhance returns and/or mitigate land risk. 
Even though we are heading to develop over 70% of lots of the use, we have systematically expanded the percentage of option lots we maintain. We continue to emphasize investing in shorter, faster-turning projects with an average investment cycle of 36 to 48 months from acquisition to completion. By focusing in on shorter-duration projects, we helped to minimize risk should a housing downturn emerge sooner than expected. 
As an example, we expect to recoup the capital we invested in the John Wieland assets in less than 4 years, and we expect fthe purchase to be accretive to company returns by year 2. 
By strategically investing in land over the past few years, we have assembled a robust land pipeline that should allow PulteGroup to grow at a rate consistent with, or ideally ahead of the overall housing market. 
Our just-completed Wieland transaction will certainly support this effort. The John Wieland Homes and Neighborhoods brand is highly regarded in the Southeast, particularly within the luxury buyer category. Beyond the opportunities we see to expand this position, we also see the potential to deploy our Pulte brand also certain Wieland positions as we work to increase volumes and accelerate the future absorption of the acquired lots. Again, by enhancing returns. 
By focusing as instantly all the quality, not just the quantity of the land assets we acquire, we put ourselves in the best position to maximize sales pace, pricing, margins and most importantly, returns on invested capital, while working to mitigate excess market risk. 
Through our Value Creation strategy, we have now put the company in a position to grow, while continuing to generate better financial performance and consistently returning funds to our shareholders. And we have done all this while taking a more conservative, lower-risk approach to our business. 
Growth, strong returns and properly managed risk, we think this is a great combination. 
Now, let me turn over the call to Bob for a more thorough review of the quarter. Bob?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Richard, and good morning. PulteGroup's Q4 financial results are a direct reflection of the meaningful improvements we continue to realize in our core homebuilding operations. As I will detail, these gains could be seen throughout our fourth qua
componenttext:
Thanks, Richard, and good morning. PulteGroup's Q4 financial results are a direct reflection of the meaningful improvements we continue to realize in our core homebuilding operations. 
As I will detail, these gains could be seen throughout our fourth quarter financial statements. 
Fourth quarter homebuilding revenues totaled $2 billion, which is up 12% from prior year revenues of $1.8 billion. The increase in Q4 revenue is driven by a 7% increase in closings to 5,662 homes, combined with a 6% increase in average sales price, $353,000. Although not a metric we manage against, the 5,662 homes closed in the fourth quarter equates to a backlog conversion rate of 65%. 
As we addressed on our most recent calls, we are working to close the year-over-year performance gap we've experienced with regard to getting homes delivered. We're pleased with the progress we've made in the fourth quarter. 
Having said that, the challenges we in the industry face with regard to labor resources and extended land development time lines are not likely to improve in the near term. We believe, however, that our decisions to prudently increase that production should help us to maintain a more consistent build cadence going forward.
In the quarter, closings by brand were as follows: 19% of homes were from Centex communities; 55% were from Pulte community; and 26% were from Del Webb. In the fourth quarter of last year, closings from Centex, Pulte and Del Webb were 24%, 46% and 30%, respectively. 
Given the profile of projects we're investing in, coupled with the projected impact of assets acquired in the Wieland transaction, we believe that describing our customers by buyer group rather than by brand, will better represent the makeup of our business. As a result, beginning in Q1, we will address buyer groups rather than brands. 
In the fourth quarter, closings by buyer group were as follows: 31% were first-time buyers; 40% were move-up buyers; and 29% were active-adult buyers. In 2014, closings by buyer group were 34% first time, 33%, move-up; and 33%, active-adult. The company recorded gross margins of 23.5% in the fourth quarter, which is up 40 basis points over the prior year. 
As has been an ongoing trend, fourth quarter margins were enhanced by higher option and lot premium revenues. In fact, option revenues in the quarter increased 10% or $4,976 per closing while lot premiums gained 16% or $1,868 per closing. 
Sales discounts remained modest at just 2.2% or $8,026 per home compared with 2.1% or $7,040 per home last year. Since implementing our strategic pricing programs since 2011 is part of our Value Creation strategy, option revenues per home have increased by $19,800 or 58%, while lot premiums per home has increased by approximately $7,100 or 107%. 
We believe our more strategic approach to pricing has been a key contributor to the high gross margins we continue to maintain. 
Reported fourth quarter SG&A expense of $139 million were 7% home sale revenues including the benefit of a $30 million reversal of content-related insurance reserves. 
Reported prior year SG&A expense of $146 million or 8.2% of home sale revenues reflected a $15 million reversal of construction-related insurance reserves. 
Looking at the full year, our reported SG&A of $590 million, which was 10.2% of homebuilding revenues, includes the benefit of $62 million or 110 basis points associated with certain legal settlements and reserve reversals. 
PulteGroup's financial services segment reported fourth quarter pretax income of $29 million, which includes the reversal of $12 million of mortgage repurchase reserves. The decision to reduce reserves is based on probaly settlements of various repurchase requests and current conditions. 
Mortgage capture rate in Q4 was 83%, up from 81% in the prior year. I'd like to take a moment to highlight the efforts of our financial services team including title, immediate challenges to the new regulatory environment under trade. Our teams did a tremendous job in closing Pulte mortgage loans [indiscernible] since supporting our customers under the new homes. Our President and CEO of financial services, and her team are recognized leaders in the industry and did a fantastic job implementing the changes needed to operate within the new trade guidelines. 
Looking at net income for the fourth quarter, reported $228 million or $0.64 per share, which includes $0.07 per share benefit from insurance and mortgage reserve reversals taken in the quarter. Our per share earnings were calculated using approximately 352 million shares outstanding for the quarter, which is down 6% from last year, largely as a result of our share repurchase activities. 
As part of our income statement review, we want to provide some thoughts about 2016. Given our backlog and anticipated land, labor and material cost, we expect 2016 homebuilding margins, inclusive of the dilutive effect of the Wieland transaction, to remain high within the range of 21.5% to 22%. This annual margin guide includes the negative impact for the Wieland transaction of approximately 100 basis points in the first quarter, 80 points in the second quarter and 50 basis points in each of the third and fourth quarters. 
Looking at our projected SG&A, we expect that our full year spend will be approximately 10% of homebuilding revenues. Consistent with prior years, this will be impacted on a quarterly basis by the size of our closings. Based on the margin and overhead guidance we just provided, the calculated operating margin we expect to generate in 2016 is between 11.5% and 12%. 
The operating margin we reported for 2015 was 13.2%, but this was enhanced by the 110-basis-point impact from the construction-related insurance reserve reversals we recorded during the year. When you consider that our 2016 operating margin guidance of 11.5% to 12% is being negatively impacted by roughly 70 basis points from the Wieland transaction and to factor in the 110-basis-point enhancement to 2015 operating margins, you could see that the operating margins will actually flat to slightly improve in 2016 compared to 2015. 
Given headwinds the industry is facing on land and labor cost, we're very proud to be able to maintain our strong operating margins. 
Putting all this together, the combination of expected higher closing volumes, higher ASPs and overhead leverage have us positioned for strong earnings growth in 2016. 
Moving past the income statement and reviewing our homebuilding operations, we ended the fourth quarter with a total of 6,494 homes under construction. That accounted for 30% of the homes under production, which is up from 26% this time last year. 
As discussed, we have purposely increased the amount of spec homes we have in the pipeline to help maintain a more even construction cadence. In the fourth quarter, we approved approximately 7,000 lots for purchase, excluding the Wieland assets as that deal closed in mid-January. We ended the year with 138,000 lots under control, of which approximately 42,000 lots or 31% were controlled via option. We continue to see [indiscernible] opportunities to increase our use of land options in an effort to enhance returns and to lower our overall risk profile. Of our controlled lots, approximately 23% are finished and 18% are currently under development. 
As Richard discussed, we continue to used to refine a disciplined approach to our land investments. Consistent with our land acquisition guidelines, we invested $485 million of land acquisition in Q4 and and additional $304 million for development of previously acquired lots. These investments brought our full year land-related spend to $2.3 billion. 
For the year, we invested approximately $1.2 billion to acquire new land. Looking ahead to 2016, including the money invested to acquire the Wieland assets, we have authorized $1.6 billion for land acquisition. As always, this level of investment is predicated on our continuing assessment of the market and on our ability to identifying suitable, high returning projects. 
Looking at our capital allocated to shareholders in the fourth quarter, we distributed $28 million in dividends and did not repurchase any of our stock. The net of share repurchase activities was due to the trading limitations resulting from work to close our previously disclosed term loan and to acquire the Wieland assets. We expect our share repurchase programs to become active again beginning in the first quarter of 2016. 
Based on our fourth quarter activity, we ended the year with $775 million of cash and a debt-to-capital ratio of 30%. As Richard noticed at the start of this call, we realized strong new order growth in the fourth quarter as orders were up 13% over last year to 3,659 homes. Higher orders for the period were driven by a 9% increase in absorption basis as all 3 buyer groups realized higher prices. 
It should be noted that we expect absorption paces in the first half of 2016 to be lower as we integrate the Wieland communities with their typical operating model of higher ASPs and slower absorption paces relative to Pulte averages. 
Breaking down orders by buyer group, on a year-over-year basis, our first time buyer business was flat, while move-up and active-adult orders increased 35%, 3% respectively. 
Adjusting per community count, our absorption paces were up 16% for first-time buyers, 11% for move-up buyers and 9% for active-adult buyers. On a dollar basis, orders for the fourth quarter came 24% to $1.4 billion, helping to raise the average sales price and backlog to $365,000. 
It's important to remember that normal business seasonality and its impacts on the mix of closings will typically result in lower delivered ASPs in the first quarter of each year. 
The company operated out of 620 communities during the fourth quarter, which is up 4% over the prior year. Looking ahead, we currently expect community count growth versus comparable prior year period to be in the range of 8% to 10% in the first 2 quarters of the year, increasing to 10% to 15% growth in the back half of the year. This will be our largest year-over-year increase in community count since the housing recovery began. Supported by our strong orders in the fourth quarter, we ended 2015 with a backlog of 6,731 homes valued at $2.5 billion. The growth in our year-end backlog of 15% in units and 26% in dollars compared to last year is as great momentum heading into '16. 
Now let me turn the call back to Richard.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. As Bob detailed, the company's -- the company realized meaningful improvement in our operating and financial results for the quarter. Given the strength of our operating metrics and the expansion of our land pipeline, we are in excellent posi
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. As Bob detailed, the company's -- the company realized meaningful improvement in our operating and financial results for the quarter. Given the strength of our operating metrics and the expansion of our land pipeline, we are in excellent position to grow earnings in 2016 and beyond. 
As has been our practice, let me provide a few comments on the market conditions which drove our fourth quarter results. Consistent with our Q4 increases in orders and absorption pace, we experienced generally higher buyer traffic to our communities, a pattern we realized throughout 2015. Further, many of the trends we experienced earlier in 2015 continued through Q4 with stronger demand in the better-located and on average, closer-in communities. 
Specific to the fourth quarter, buyer demand remained positive, up and down the East Coast with notable strength in the Southeast from the Carolinas down to Florida. We've talked about positive demand trends in the Southeast for a number of years. it is this trend and our expectations for long-term growth in the Southeast markets, particularly the bigger markets of Atlanta, Charleston, Charlotte and Raleigh, which made the transaction with John Wieland so compelling. 
Looking to the center of the country, demand conditions remain favorable, although we continued to experience volatility in the performance of underlying markets. Demand in the Midwest showed some positive gains as we benefited from an expanded community count in several markets. Our Texas business in Q4 was slowed by having roughly 10% fewer open communities available-for-sale versus the prior year. In addition, our Texas numbers were impacted by ongoing demand softness in the higher-priced communities in Houston, resulting from the prolonged weakness in the energy markets. Given current conditions, we are being very thoughtful about deploying additional capital in the region and will continue to carefully monitor demand throughout the state. 
The Western third of the country continued to realize excellent demand from Washington through California and through our markets in Arizona, Nevada and New Mexico. Overall, we were pleased with how demand conditions developed in the fourth quarter. We have seen a continuation of good traffic and demand trends through the first few weeks of January so we have every reason to be optimistic heading into the spring selling season. 
Consistent with our long-held expectations for a gradual but sustained recovery, 2015 new home sales of approximately 500,000 units for the country were up 15% over last year. Given the favorable market dynamics of strong job growth, accelerating household formations, supported demographic trends and continued low interest rates, we expect in home sales will continue to slow and steady path higher for the next several years. That being said, we are well aware of the volatility in the world today. Our concerns about global economic conditions to the swoon in oil prices, the gyrations to the stock market, the day to day swings can be violent. The reality is, however, that we can't control any of these factors, but what we can do is focus on running our business consistent with the goals we have established and disciplines we have demonstrated. This means acquiring well located communities that we believe can deliver high returns on investment. 
It also means hedging our bets by using more land options where possible and focusing in on smaller, shorter-duration projects where we can get our capital back quickly. It also means not over leveraging the balance sheet and keeping one hand on the levered to slow investment yet housing demand begins to change. And finally, it means having the discipline to systematically give excess funds back to shareholders better than trying to force investments in the system. 
We ended 2015 with a strong fourth quarter performance. I'm confident that we can build on these results in 2016 and further capitalize on the excellent market position I believe PulteGroup maintains today. The market position that has been built by our exceptional group of employees who work hard everyday to build great homes and deliver an unmatched home buying experience to our customers. 
Now, let me turn the call back to Jim Zeumer. Jim?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Bob Wetenhall from RBC Capital Markets

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to touch on -- you guys have really robust order growth and you also noted 7.5% decline in deliveries in Texas and orders were also soft. Can you give us a view on what you're seeing in the Texas market? And specifically, is it broad-based? Or
componenttext: Just wanted to touch on -- you guys have really robust order growth and you also noted 7.5% decline in deliveries in Texas and orders were also soft. Can you give us a view on what you're seeing in the Texas market? And specifically, is it broad-based? Or is it -- and what's going on with price points there?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, this is Richard. Overall, the higher price points in Houston continued to exhibit softness as we've discussed. Outside of Houston, I would say that we have a mix performance with some notable strength in Dallas. It seems to be the 1 market that conti
componenttext: Bob, this is Richard. Overall, the higher price points in Houston continued to exhibit softness as we've discussed. Outside of Houston, I would say that we have a mix performance with some notable strength in Dallas. It seems to be the 1 market that continues to hold up better than the rest of the markets. So overall, it's a decent housing market with the exception of the higher price points in Houston and we're being thoughtful with our investments going forward, keeping an eye on things.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. As a follow-up, great execution, it seems like you are on track with deliveries and some labor bottlenecks. Trying to understand the setup for 2016, what do you think about pace of absorption and your expectations for ASP performance? You
componenttext: That's helpful. As a follow-up, great execution, it seems like you are on track with deliveries and some labor bottlenecks. Trying to understand the setup for 2016, what do you think about pace of absorption and your expectations for ASP performance? You said that there's a volatility but then you look at some of your trends and they seem pretty strong. How should we be thinking about pricing trends for this cost? You touched on that gross margin, 21.5 to 22. What do you see confidence on ASP growth you can get there?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's a lot of stuff in that question, Bob. I think in terms of ASP growth, we don't factor that into our expectation, what we've got -- a third of the year [ph] and backlog, we've got an expectation that we've got relatively benign input cost this year
componenttext: There's a lot of stuff in that question, Bob. I think in terms of ASP growth, we don't factor that into our expectation, what we've got -- a third of the year [ph] and backlog, we've got an expectation that we've got relatively benign input cost this year. So numbers trending positively basically all the other input costs we see about a 2% increase maybe in our house cost construction, that's largely labor. We're obviously working through that in all different markets. So we have visibility into that part of the year and at least in terms of input costs, we think that we're in relatively good shape coming into the year.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Stephen Kim from Barclays.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Stephen Kim from Barclays.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, strong quarter. Impressive results. Wanted to ask you a little bit about your breakout of the first time move-up and active-adult. Just one, could two clarifying questions on that. First of all, you said that in 4Q, I think it was 31% first time, 40%
componenttext: Yes, strong quarter. Impressive results. Wanted to ask you a little bit about your breakout of the first time move-up and active-adult. Just one, could two clarifying questions on that. First of all, you said that in 4Q, I think it was 31% first time, 40% move up, and then you gave some rough numbers [ph] about 1/3, 1/3, for '14. Just wanted to make sure that was full year '14 versus fourth quarter of '14. And if you could remind me again the definition of first time versus move-up. I mean, are you actually asking them? Is this the first time you've ever owned a home, or are you sort of putting sort of a demarcation based on price points, on what you think a typical first-time buyer would be buying.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Stephen, to the first question, that is Q4 data, not full year. And to the second question, we actually have what we call targeted consumer groups and so it's based on the type of product we're building and the location of it that tells us who the buyer g
componenttext: Stephen, to the first question, that is Q4 data, not full year. And to the second question, we actually have what we call targeted consumer groups and so it's based on the type of product we're building and the location of it that tells us who the buyer groups are. And so the first time designation is just an aggregation of the targeted consumer groups that serve people who are buying their first homes as opposed to move-up. But just to clarify, I think we've talked about this on a couple of calls. The flagging of those differ somewhat so there -- for that millennial buyer that's closer in, typically higher price point, we flag them full fee, but they are really first-time buyers. That's the primary difference there. And then there are certain active-adult penetrations that we have historically and will continue to flag Pulte, not Del Webb, that will get caught in the active-adult categorization as opposed to again, being a Pulte flag.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And I think that's obviously an important distinction to make because obviously, we've been -- well, not obviously, but we've been seeing a pickup in first-time buyers activity that doesn't seem to really have manifested in entry-level product per
componenttext: Right. And I think that's obviously an important distinction to make because obviously, we've been -- well, not obviously, but we've been seeing a pickup in first-time buyers activity that doesn't seem to really have manifested in entry-level product per se. But that would be consistent with an idea that the guy who, let's say, wants a 26, 27 year-old 6 years ago is now older and probably in the market, maybe buying a slightly different product than he would have 6 years ago. I guess, my question generally would be, as you lay out your community count growth, as you think about how you're going to be utilizing the Wieland land with some of your products and just generally, as you position your business in 2016 and '17, how specifically or discreetly are you targeting a first time buyer who may be looking to sort of buy a product, which historically might have been considered a little bit more of a move-up -- a first time move-up kind of a product. How much are you actually positioning ourselves for the emergence of that kind of a buyer in marketplace and an increase in that demand?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Steve, this is Richard. That's exactly what we're doing. As an organization, I think we've talked about the millennial study that we completed in 2015, which showed what we believe to be significant opportunity for a buyer that is probably in their e
componenttext: Yes, Steve, this is Richard. That's exactly what we're doing. As an organization, I think we've talked about the millennial study that we completed in 2015, which showed what we believe to be significant opportunity for a buyer that is probably in their early to mid-30s and who hasn't owned a home before, so they're called a first time buyer but they're spending $300,000 to $400,000 on urban townhome products. So overall, our categorization that Bob described, we think, more accurately depicts how we're attending to serve the business as those buyers will be captured in that first category. And we are investing in several of our major cities in that buyer category and that's part of the contributing change in ASP that you see in our backlog and in our continued guidance going forward, that's part of the Pulte story here.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to follow up on that ASP point, Richard. The average selling price of the first time home is about $264,000. When you compare that to the historical pricing that we've disclosed for Centex, that entry-level business, that's roughly $200,000. Ther
componenttext: And just to follow up on that ASP point, Richard. The average selling price of the first time home is about $264,000. When you compare that to the historical pricing that we've disclosed for Centex, that entry-level business, that's roughly $200,000. There is a definite difference in the products that we're offering, the location we're offering in there.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Nishu Sood from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Nishu Sood from Deutsche Bank.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me add strong results in the fourth quarter so congratulations on that. The first question I wanted to ask was, the absorption trend was very nice in the fourth quarter and counter to what what we see generally, I think, from the industry, 9% absorpti
componenttext: Let me add strong results in the fourth quarter so congratulations on that. The first question I wanted to ask was, the absorption trend was very nice in the fourth quarter and counter to what what we see generally, I think, from the industry, 9% absorption growth, and that was on a lower level of community count growth. Are you expecting quite strong community count growth, 10% to 15%, I believe, you said, year-over-year by the end of the year. So typically with new community openings that might dampen absorption at first, how would that trend then carry through or how would you anticipate that trend getting through into '16? Is it going to be diluted by a lot of these new communities that are going to be coming on? Or do you think there's enough momentum that you might be able to sustain that?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of comments. To be clear, our 13% sign-up growth was driven by 4% community count growth and 9% improvement in absorption rates on like stores, so we're very pleased with that. And before I answer your question, I just want to point out that
componenttext: Just a couple of comments. To be clear, our 13% sign-up growth was driven by 4% community count growth and 9% improvement in absorption rates on like stores, so we're very pleased with that. And before I answer your question, I just want to point out that we believe that underlying strength and absorption rates is primarily driven by excellent land positions. And we've been talking for several years how we believe we are doing an excellent job of positioning our communities, not just growing for growth's sake. Having said that, with regard to our 2016, two things.  Number one, we're going to have nice community count growth this year but it will be a little less in Q1 and 2 as Bob indicated and then more in Q3 and 4. Although strong, really, all 4 quarters. So that factor, we would expect absorption rates in Q1 to be impacted there. But probably more notably, as we work to integrate the Wieland business, that business is typically a higher price point, slower absorption model, and that, as we integrate it, will impact our results, particularly earlier in the year. So just trying to make sure that everyone's expectations factored that into their overall models. So we're very pleased with the way the trends are playing out for '16, particularly as it relates to earnings growth overall. But those factors will play in.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's helpful. And then second question, on the margin outlook, which Bob, I think, you laid out pretty well, the capitalized interest that is flowing through the gross margin line has been an important tailwind for the overall gross margins. It
componenttext: Got it. That's helpful. And then second question, on the margin outlook, which Bob, I think, you laid out pretty well, the capitalized interest that is flowing through the gross margin line has been an important tailwind for the overall gross margins. It was certainly the case in 4Q as well as for overall '15. How do you expect that to trend in '16? Should we take the percentage of revenues that are representative in 4Q and maybe carry that forward? Could you give us some thoughts on that?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a great question. And essentially, if you think about it, we've got a lag between when we incur cost and when we expense it's. And we've had the benefit of the past few years of debt pay down. That, obviously, has mitigated in the most recent ye
componenttext: Yes, it's a great question. And essentially, if you think about it, we've got a lag between when we incur cost and when we expense it's. And we've had the benefit of the past few years of debt pay down. That, obviously, has mitigated in the most recent years. If you look at our current full year '15, our cash interest expense was about $128 million. The expense that we recognized through the income statement was $138 million. So they're getting closer together. So there will be a much smaller delta. I think in absolute terms, we were 57 -- $57 million benefit for interest in '15 that number will be smaller in 2016. Again, reflecting of the fact that basically, we're costing off of what we're expensing.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Rehaut from JP Morgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Rehaut from JP Morgan.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question I wanted to delve in a little bit around the gross margins as well. And I appreciate the insights there. And I think if I understand you correctly, Bob, you're saying that the amortized interest for '16 will trend closer to that 1 28. Is th
componenttext: First question I wanted to delve in a little bit around the gross margins as well. And I appreciate the insights there. And I think if I understand you correctly, Bob, you're saying that the amortized interest for '16 will trend closer to that 1 28. Is that fair?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't given any detail but it's going to be a much smaller delta than it has been.
componenttext: We haven't given any detail but it's going to be a much smaller delta than it has been.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. So you're just trying to get into the components then of the preinterest gross margin and get some of your sense of the puts and takes there. 4Q, '15 down about 100 or 90 basis points year-over-year. What were the key drivers of that? And it was al
componenttext: Right. So you're just trying to get into the components then of the preinterest gross margin and get some of your sense of the puts and takes there. 4Q, '15 down about 100 or 90 basis points year-over-year. What were the key drivers of that? And it was also down sequentially. I just wanted to get your sense of, if labor was a big part, if there was a mix shift, if there was land cost, what were the kind of drivers? And also, as we think about 2016, I know you highlighted the Wieland acquisition being about a 70-basis-point drag, but what would the other components of that -- of the year-over-year change be?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Mike, I think you summarized it well. There is about 70 basis points of detriment that we expect in '16 from the Wieland acquisition. And then if you look at it, the margin profile of the business, thinking about it from consumer groups, is -- as has
componenttext: Yes, Mike, I think you summarized it well. There is about 70 basis points of detriment that we expect in '16 from the Wieland acquisition. And then if you look at it, the margin profile of the business, thinking about it from consumer groups, is -- as has been the case for years, the most --  the highest margin is going to be our active-adult. Interestingly, when you look at it, the first time business actually enjoys very high margins for 2 reasons. One, that millennial business that we talked about is a very strong margin business for us and for the historical Centex business, since we haven't been investing many of the lots that we're running through now are older so they enjoy strong margins. And then that move-up business, which is where we've done most of our investment over the last 3 or 4 years, still enjoying very good margins. But because of the higher land cost and labor costs that we're seeing, it's, today, of the 3, although still strong, the lower margin business. And so the mix shift towards that has implications to our deposit margins. So 70 basis points from Wieland, mix shift and labor cost, probably the biggest driver of margin. Otherwise, in 2016.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Lovallo for Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Lovallo for Merrill Lynch.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question I had is, you gave a lot of detail on the purchase accounting effect from the Wieland acquisition on gross margin. Just curious about how you're expecting kind of SG&A to trend through 2016, given some of the integration cost and then movin
componenttext: First question I had is, you gave a lot of detail on the purchase accounting effect from the Wieland acquisition on gross margin. Just curious about how you're expecting kind of SG&A to trend through 2016, given some of the integration cost and then moving past that once it's fully integrated is the $165 million kind of quarterly run rate still a good number, or do you think that would actually go up a bit?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We actually are -- instead of targeting dollars, we're putting -- trying to get things more aligned with industry and say okay, relative to sales, this isn't always what it is. So we think 10%, obviously, the seasonality of the business with lower closing
componenttext: We actually are -- instead of targeting dollars, we're putting -- trying to get things more aligned with industry and say okay, relative to sales, this isn't always what it is. So we think 10%, obviously, the seasonality of the business with lower closings in the first of the year, higher closings, you can and should expect to see that be a richer number be higher than 10% in the first couple of quarters and lower, likely what we did in the fourth quarter this year. Certainly, there will be some integration cost associated with Wieland that we would expect over time to be able to narrow out of the business. But the 10% that we've projected for '16 is inclusive of that.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And john, this is Richard. a little color also. The 10% guidance provided, when you factor in the contraction reversal impact in the 2015 numbers, you can see that we're getting substantial leverage in '16 as we expect to grow.
componenttext: And john, this is Richard. a little color also. The 10% guidance provided, when you factor in the contraction reversal impact in the 2015 numbers, you can see that we're getting substantial leverage in '16 as we expect to grow.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then in terms of maybe just give us an update on kind of your spec strategy and how that progressed in the quarter, and again, in the third quarter with something like 340 finished back homes and where did you close out the year?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then in terms of maybe just give us an update on kind of your spec strategy and how that progressed in the quarter, and again, in the third quarter with something like 340 finished back homes and where did you close out the year?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so we finished back in the end of the year was 471 units, which is actually down about 2% for prior year. We started that spec really in the third quarter so they weren't finished at the end of the year so you'll see that come through in our first qu
componenttext: Yes, so we finished back in the end of the year was 471 units, which is actually down about 2% for prior year. We started that spec really in the third quarter so they weren't finished at the end of the year so you'll see that come through in our first quarter and second quarter results. But total spec, we talked about -- at about 30% of our starts compared to 24% historically. So it's not a big change, and I think what you can and should expect us to do is to manage against not letting finished specs get really heavy.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And John, and everyone else, just to remind everyone, the reason that we're increasing our spec production a little bit is to help us with the quarterly cadence of closing, not trying to run quite as tight as we were with recent inventory and we think tha
componenttext: And John, and everyone else, just to remind everyone, the reason that we're increasing our spec production a little bit is to help us with the quarterly cadence of closing, not trying to run quite as tight as we were with recent inventory and we think that's going to help us moving forward.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Alan Ratner from Zelman & Associates.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Alan Ratner from Zelman & Associates.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Richard, just on your comments on January. It seems like it's holding up pretty well. Curious if what you're hearing on the ground from your active adult buyers, given the stock market volatility. Has there been any -- have you noticed any discernible tre
componenttext: Richard, just on your comments on January. It seems like it's holding up pretty well. Curious if what you're hearing on the ground from your active adult buyers, given the stock market volatility. Has there been any -- have you noticed any discernible trends there, versus more of the first timer or maybe first time move up product? Because that is a very discretionary buyer. I imagine they're looking at their 401(k) portfolios and they might be a little bit skittish. So just curious what you're seeing from that subset of buyers currently.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Alan, that's a great question. We've been paying attention and so far we've not seen a change.
componenttext: Alan, that's a great question. We've been paying attention and so far we've not seen a change.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's good to hear. And second, on the spec strategy, is there any contemplation within the gross margin guidance next year for specs to represent a greater percentage of your sales? And assuming that is the case, so what's the margin differential runnin
componenttext: That's good to hear. And second, on the spec strategy, is there any contemplation within the gross margin guidance next year for specs to represent a greater percentage of your sales? And assuming that is the case, so what's the margin differential running up currently between your spec and to be build sales?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, well certainly, Allen, we factor that into our guidance as we put together our plans for the year. People do what they were going to try and start in terms of spec. In terms of actual performance, I would tell you that recent activity would tell you
componenttext: Yes, well certainly, Allen, we factor that into our guidance as we put together our plans for the year. People do what they were going to try and start in terms of spec. In terms of actual performance, I would tell you that recent activity would tell you that there is a very consistent with historical trend where your dirt sales have the highest margins. We're actually seeing that people are contracting before framing that the margins hold up and stay consistent and then we have a couple of hundred basis points of degradation on spec that it's finished. So again, I think one of the things we're really focused on is let's not get that finished spec to be a big drag on our margins going forward.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Megan McGrath from MKM Partners.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Megan McGrath from MKM Partners.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow up a little bit on the absorption pace. The nice improvement you had in the quarter. In your commentary, you'd stated that you feel like that driver is primarily because of the location of your communities. But I assume that, that
componenttext: I just wanted to follow up a little bit on the absorption pace. The nice improvement you had in the quarter. In your commentary, you'd stated that you feel like that driver is primarily because of the location of your communities. But I assume that, that location didn't change too much quarter-to-quarter. So is there anything specific in the fourth quarter that you think drove that sort of incremental increase? It doesn't feel like overall new home sales accelerated. In fact, maybe decelerated a little bit. So what specific do you guys change, let's say third quarter or fourth quarter, which helped that absorption pace in your view?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Megan, there is volatility typically quarter to quarter. But I would point out, this is the third or fourth quarter out of the last, maybe 4 or 5 that we have include absorption paces. So I believe that that's a factor. I would also say that as our common
componenttext: Megan, there is volatility typically quarter to quarter. But I would point out, this is the third or fourth quarter out of the last, maybe 4 or 5 that we have include absorption paces. So I believe that that's a factor. I would also say that as our commonly managed for plants continue to grow as a component of our total, those are very well-designed and frankly sell better than the noncommonly managed floor plants. So that's a factor. But I would -- I would continue to highlight that well-placed land, we're focused on quality of land, not just quantity of land as the primary driver, in my opinion. Vis-à-vis maybe what some others in the industry have talked about.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I wanted to follow up on SG&A a little bit too, as well. I apologize if I missed part of your answer before. But I know there's a lot of moving parts here in some of the numbers. So It looks like you're looking for, if we X out the benefits this
componenttext: Okay. And I wanted to follow up on SG&A a little bit too, as well. I apologize if I missed part of your answer before. But I know there's a lot of moving parts here in some of the numbers. So It looks like you're looking for, if we X out the benefits this year were pretty meaningful year-over-year improvement in SG&A. Looks like about 100-plus basis points, if I have that right. But also looking for a pretty good increase in gross income added to accounts, which I would usually associated with maybe some accelerating SG&A levels, so if you could maybe talk us through your confidence in being able to sort of grow SG&A at a rate even though you're accelerating your community count growth, that would be great.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Megan, a big driver of the community count growth is Wieland. And so we opened 200 communities this year. We'll open some numbers similar to that next year. So there really isn't a significant driver there. It's in terms of community count growth, a lot o
componenttext: Megan, a big driver of the community count growth is Wieland. And so we opened 200 communities this year. We'll open some numbers similar to that next year. So there really isn't a significant driver there. It's in terms of community count growth, a lot of it is going to be present that we can get 1 big chunk.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Richard. I think you highlighted it appropriately. We are anticipating growth in earnings and certainly in volume this year. And that provides leverage overall. So we're not giving an SG&A dollar number, but we do expect to leverage our overheads
componenttext: This is Richard. I think you highlighted it appropriately. We are anticipating growth in earnings and certainly in volume this year. And that provides leverage overall. So we're not giving an SG&A dollar number, but we do expect to leverage our overheads and you were right with your guidance or your commentary, if you will, on that.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Dahl from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Dahl from Crédit Suisse.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back to that margin discussion and I think you addressed it with both Mike Rehaut's question and Alan. But in terms of some of the mix shift, you have two things going on. You've got selling through some of the legacy-Centex stuff that was
componenttext: I wanted to go back to that margin discussion and I think you addressed it with both Mike Rehaut's question and Alan. But in terms of some of the mix shift, you have two things going on. You've got selling through some of the legacy-Centex stuff that was higher-margin and transitioning both to the move-up product and the recent vintage. So I just wanted to get your sense of this margin erosion that you're seeing in '16. Do you think you're fully run rating what the kind of go forward mix will be? Or is there still some to kind of transition out? This is still being lifted a little bit by the 20% or so of the communities that are still legacy Centex? Any additional detail you could give there.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, honestly, we will -- as the year goes on, share what the breakdown is by consumer group. I don't know that we would want to give quarterly forward guidance that would be community specific, Mike. So I think there certainly continued to be a mix shif
componenttext: Well, honestly, we will -- as the year goes on, share what the breakdown is by consumer group. I don't know that we would want to give quarterly forward guidance that would be community specific, Mike. So I think there certainly continued to be a mix shift took we've invested largely in that move-up already so you'll see that continue to play out.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Richard. I think it's worth noting that we're extremely pleased with our margin projection for '16. When you factor in the known headwinds from a new acquisition, we're pretty pleased with how margins are holding up when you combine that with what
componenttext: This is Richard. I think it's worth noting that we're extremely pleased with our margin projection for '16. When you factor in the known headwinds from a new acquisition, we're pretty pleased with how margins are holding up when you combine that with what we expect to be good SG&A leverage and strong growth, our operating margins, we continue to be very pleased with. So yes, there' are certainly some anticipated core declines from higher input costs that Bob mentioned. But on a relative basis, we like our margin position a lot.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And clearly, coming from a point of strength, I guess, then, Richard, on that last point on the acquisition, once we get through the, maybe this is for Bob, once we get through the purchase accounting headwinds, which I believe you said 17 basis points dr
componenttext: And clearly, coming from a point of strength, I guess, then, Richard, on that last point on the acquisition, once we get through the, maybe this is for Bob, once we get through the purchase accounting headwinds, which I believe you said 17 basis points drag for the full year, how should we think about that margin relative to what your legacy business has been producing? I think that was understanding, was that maybe been a competitive deal, so it's this ones we get through purchase accounting, the 20% margin business or is it really closer to what we've seen out of your legacy business in the past year or so?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't given anything beyond '16. I would tell you, we see opportunities to reduce costs and enhance bases to drive higher returns and that's what we're going to work towards. We get 2017. We'll share what our total margins are to the extent that it's
componenttext: We haven't given anything beyond '16. I would tell you, we see opportunities to reduce costs and enhance bases to drive higher returns and that's what we're going to work towards. We get 2017. We'll share what our total margins are to the extent that it's relevant, we'll share what the impact of Wieland is to that.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Stephen East from Evercore ISI.
componenttext: The next question comes from Stephen East from Evercore ISI.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Richard, maybe the first one. With John Wieland, could you talk a little bit about what drove your decision process. I know you all are always looking at acquisitions land price. But more expensively, what was the attraction and how specific was it to Joh
componenttext: Richard, maybe the first one. With John Wieland, could you talk a little bit about what drove your decision process. I know you all are always looking at acquisitions land price. But more expensively, what was the attraction and how specific was it to John Wieland versus, or are you all still actively engaged and looking for more acquisition opportunities, that type of thing?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steve, that's a great question. Let me first confirm your comment that all acquisitions are looked at through the land limbs and we're pleased with the economics of the deal overall. And as Bob mentioned, the ability to put some Pulte efficiency, if you w
componenttext: Steve, that's a great question. Let me first confirm your comment that all acquisitions are looked at through the land limbs and we're pleased with the economics of the deal overall. And as Bob mentioned, the ability to put some Pulte efficiency, if you will, into what we saw there. And a part of that, you might have noted in our script, we're intending to take some Wieland assets and Pulte product on it to help accelerate absorptions and drive returns. So we're feeling really great about that. Beyond that, this particular transaction had significant brand value in our mind. And for buyers in the southeast, the John Wieland name commands a premium. And when you factor that into the strategic pricing programs, the focus on option revenue and lot premium revenue gets a really nice fit into the way we've been driving margins in the business. And we feel like it's a real consistent approach toward driving high returns. So the brand value there is exciting. And candidly, even the value of the Wieland name from an entitlement standpoint, we feel pretty good about going forward. We want to grow our business in the Southeast and the Wieland repuation's exciting, allowing is to get into some of these core infill locations, millennial locations. So a very, very strong, recognized consumer brand in the southeast that gives us opportunity, along with the strong land positions.  And then potentially, lastly, I'll mention the southeast, Steve, we like. Vis-à-vis some other markets, we think the southeast is not overheated . We think the southeast has got a lot of runway in front of it. And complementary assets that are not cannibalizing anything else, we felt good about. And just on your last point, we continue to stay actively looking at any transaction that come our way. We've been very, very disciplined to make sure that economics work.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then Bob, did I hear you right, did you say land spend in '16 would be $1.6 billion? Or were you just talking about the acquisition side of it? Can you give me a little clarity there? And where you would be? Are you reallocating more towards this firs
componenttext: And then Bob, did I hear you right, did you say land spend in '16 would be $1.6 billion? Or were you just talking about the acquisition side of it? Can you give me a little clarity there? And where you would be? Are you reallocating more towards this first-time buyer? I know not active-adult, but first-time buyer away from the move-up buyer? And just maybe a bit broader on your net debt targets. Are you comfortable where your debt is now, or do you want to take it lower reverse repo, that type of thing?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So to your first question, that $1.6 billion that we highlighted was just land acquisition. We will obviously have development spend on top of that. In terms of where we're spending that money, wr still agnostic. Over time, we have told folks, go find the
componenttext: So to your first question, that $1.6 billion that we highlighted was just land acquisition. We will obviously have development spend on top of that. In terms of where we're spending that money, wr still agnostic. Over time, we have told folks, go find the best deals, what that have yielded over the last few years is mostly move-up and that millennial core business that we've talked about. I don't see anything at the moment that tells me it's going to be anything different in the future. But certainly, as and when, for instance, is that true entry-level buyer becomes more robust in terms of paces and return makes sense, we've always talked about a willingness and desire to do that. And then to your last point on net debt, 30%, 30.5% at the end of the year. We are very comfortable with that. We've laid out a target range of 30% to 40%. So we're very comfortable with our GAAP balance sheet position and liquidity. So we've got plenty of choice, candidly. We've increased the dividend starting here in the first quarter. We didn't get to do any share repurchase during the quarter, and you could expect to see us do some of that going forward and obviously, we think we can do that all in the context of the land spend that we outlined.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from the line of Will Randow from Citigroup.
componenttext: The next question comes from the line of Will Randow from Citigroup.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a question on the mortgage business in regards to how you're thinking about normalizing underwriting standards, if possible, what levers you can pull? And if you can talk about the difficulties in implementing the new [indiscernible] before the
componenttext: I just had a question on the mortgage business in regards to how you're thinking about normalizing underwriting standards, if possible, what levers you can pull? And if you can talk about the difficulties in implementing the new [indiscernible] before the [indiscernible] in terms of more mortgage closings elongated, et cetera.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I'll take the first one, Will. In terms of overall underwriting standards, they remain fairly consistent. They continue to be tight. And we're governed by the same rules that everyone else is, so no real changing outlook there. Maybe on the margin, it
componenttext: So I'll take the first one, Will. In terms of overall underwriting standards, they remain fairly consistent. They continue to be tight. And we're governed by the same rules that everyone else is, so no real changing outlook there. Maybe on the margin, it continues to ease just very, very slightly but overall, not much change. And then maybe Bob.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And with respect to the rules, I think again, we think we've got the best team in the business. We think about change well in advance of it, programmatically, systematically. So I don't see it being an impediment and I know they'll say gosh, there's a lot
componenttext: And with respect to the rules, I think again, we think we've got the best team in the business. We think about change well in advance of it, programmatically, systematically. So I don't see it being an impediment and I know they'll say gosh, there's a lot of hard work behind that. But they've got a very clear calendar of the things that are coming at us, to think about it strategically. So again, I wanted to make it sound easy but the trade that affected this fourth quarter, it really did not impact our closings and that's a testament to the work that we're doing there.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Susan Maklari from UBS Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Susan Maklari from UBS Securities.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: In terms of the labor side, can you talk a little bit about what you're seeing there? It seems like with the -- the progress you make in closing homes and the talk around your spec strategy, are you seeing any incremental using there, perhaps some of the
componenttext: In terms of the labor side, can you talk a little bit about what you're seeing there? It seems like with the -- the progress you make in closing homes and the talk around your spec strategy, are you seeing any incremental using there, perhaps some of the [indiscernible] gaining more confidence in what's going on in the market?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Susan, I don't think we're seeing a real easing. I think we're getting a little bit better in managing through it by not being quite as tight with our spec inventory change, if you will. We give ourselves a few more targets to shoot at each quarter to acc
componenttext: Susan, I don't think we're seeing a real easing. I think we're getting a little bit better in managing through it by not being quite as tight with our spec inventory change, if you will. We give ourselves a few more targets to shoot at each quarter to account for any up and downs that may occur in the market. But labor continues to be tight. There's not a lot of new labor that's flowing in to the space. So I do think that the industry and us, particularly, are getting a little better at managing through it but it's going to be with us for a while.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: But the ability to give that labor market that came in a consistent view that says we've got the following work, you're going to keep our crews busy, we're going to get pulled off and off the site. We think we'll have real benefit in terms of our ability
componenttext: But the ability to give that labor market that came in a consistent view that says we've got the following work, you're going to keep our crews busy, we're going to get pulled off and off the site. We think we'll have real benefit in terms of our ability to produce it timely.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttextpreview: I'm curious about how to think about your land's strategy. Obviously, the option components crept up to about 1/3 of the inventory now. But then I think in the prepared comments, you said 70% of the land spend was for undeveloped. Should we think that the
componenttext: I'm curious about how to think about your land's strategy. Obviously, the option components crept up to about 1/3 of the inventory now. But then I think in the prepared comments, you said 70% of the land spend was for undeveloped. Should we think that the option percentage is going to continue to creep up a little, or is this a signal that maybe, to maintain those margins, you're going to have to go out and do more of the development side?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jack, what we really are trying to say is we are really paying attention to managing the risk side of the land component. The fact that we're having to develop 70% plus is just a factor of the way the land comes to us in the market, but that doesn't mean
componenttext: Jack, what we really are trying to say is we are really paying attention to managing the risk side of the land component. The fact that we're having to develop 70% plus is just a factor of the way the land comes to us in the market, but that doesn't mean we can't break those takes into 2, 3, 4 takes with options to mitigate risk. And we want to highlight that on Wieland candidly, because some of the reports I saw showed people talking about buying 8 or 10 or 12 years worth of land and we expect to recoup all of our capital in less than 4 years on that deal. So we're very, very focused on mitigating risk from that perspective. So in terms of option percentage, I would hope that we can continue to drive that forward. The market will dictate that, but agnostic to options or development or not, the key is we're managing risk very differently than we did in the past. Buying 10 or 12 years worth of land at one time is a very, very rare event today for the company and will continue to be going forward.
