headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Carol, and I will be a conference operator today. At this time, I would like welcome everyone to the Q1 2016 PulteGroup, Inc. earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn today's call over to Mr. Jim
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Carol, and I will be a conference operator today. At this time, I would like welcome everyone to the Q1 2016 PulteGroup, Inc. earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn today's call over to Mr. Jim Zeumer.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Carol, and let me welcome everyone to today's conference call discussing PulteGroup's first quarter financial results for the 3 months ended March 31, 2016. And joining me for today's call are Richard Dugas, Chairman, President and CEO;
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Carol, and let me welcome everyone to today's conference call discussing PulteGroup's first quarter financial results for the 3 months ended March 31, 2016. And joining me for today's call are Richard Dugas, Chairman, President and CEO; [indiscernible] President; Bob O'Shaughnessy, Executive Vice President and CFO; Jim Ossowski, Vice President, Finance and Controller. A copy of this morning's earnings release and the presentation slides that accompanies today's call have been posted to our corporate website at pultegroupinc.com. We will also post an audio replay of today's call later this afternoon.
Before we begin the discussion, I want to alert everyone, all the participants that today's presentation may include forward-looking statements about PulteGroup's future performance. Actual results could differ materially from those suggested by our comments made today.  The most significant risk factors that could affect future results are summarized as part of today's earnings release and within the accompanying presentation slides. These risk factors and other key information are detailed in our SEC filings, including our annual and quarterly reports.
Now let me turn the call over to Richard Dugas. Richard?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim, and good morning, everyone. Some of you may have seen the letter issued yesterday by Bill [indiscernible] where his grandson's performance on the CNBC yesterday. As there is nothing new in Bill's letter, we will not be responding to these att
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim, and good morning, everyone. Some of you may have seen the letter issued yesterday by Bill [indiscernible] where his grandson's performance on the CNBC yesterday. As there is nothing new in Bill's letter, we will not be responding to these attacks or otherwise be discussing the on this call. Other than to say though we stand by the completeness and accuracy of our previous disclosures. We run this company for the benefit of all shareholders and we'll continue to do so. I've had opportunity these past few weeks to speak with many of our largest holders, and that's encouraging to hear your support for our entire leadership team, our Board of Directors and our Value Creation strategy. I want to take this opportunity to ensure all that investors we are busy running this company and remains squarely focused on continuing to deliver value for you.
To that point, we are extremely pleased with the strength of our first quarter results. Consistent with our strategy and our efforts to enhance returns on invested capital, for the past few years, we have highlighted strategic pricing, construction productivity and balance sheet efficiency as drivers of our performance. Our financial results over the past few years reflect these drivers as we realized significant gains in pretax profitability despite only modest gains in production volumes.
Many of you have seen the graph in our presentation which we included in today's conference call slides, which shows are pretax income, improving $1.1 billion over the past 5 years on just a 12% increase in closings. We have communicated that 2016 would be an inflection year, with increasing volume being delivered to a much more efficient homebuilding operation. The combination of rising unit volumes, increasing average sales prices and the more efficient homebuilding machine can translate into significant earnings growth. Add in the benefit of consistently returning funds to shareholders, and you have a business that can produce high returns for its investors overtime.
As Bob will detail in a moment, the business has begun to turn in that direction, with signups increased by 10% to almost 5,700 homes. Closing volumes gaining 17% to almost 4,000 closings, average selling prices expanding by 9% to $353,000, and our backlog value climbing 31% to $3.4 billion. These metrics, obviously, resulted in a strong quarterly performance in the first quarter, but equally important, they position the company to deliver continued growth over the balance of 2016.
While our Q1 numbers and our expectations for 2016 point to increase in scale, we have not and will not lose our focus on our primary objective, to run a business that can deliver better returns over the housing cycle and do so with less risk. We believe that the onset of his housing recovery that it would be more gradual than the v-shape rebound typical of those housing cycles. Our thesis is unchanged as we expected and extended recovery will continue to unfold for the next several years supported by improving economy, favorable demographics, years of relative underbuilding and the supportive mortgage rate environment.
Given these dynamics, we have been increasing our investment in the business but have done so in a disciplined manner by emphasizing smaller projects while expanding our use of options when possible. This has served as extraordinary years of land supply helping to mitigate market risk. We have also focused our land investments on closer end locations where we think demand is more sustainable when the market ultimately takes a breather. We have excepted a trade-off of having up a certain positions on where we can be more confident in their future performance.
As evidence of our focus on driving returns and reducing risk relative to prior business practices, consider that our supply of owned lots has fallen from approximately 8.5 years in 2010 to roughly 5.5 years in 2015. Based on our land acquisition discipline, expected sales cases, as we work and to some alert longer in older communities, we look forward -- excuse me, we look for our own supply to continue trending lower in the future. Among the reasons for the decline is that improve land deals and over the past 5 years have averaged roughly 125 controlled lots for community, and this includes 31 new Del Webb projects over that timeframe that have averaged just over 500 controlled lots each.
Along with how we manage land, our more disciplined approach extends to the management of the company's entire balance sheet. Bob and his team have done an outstanding job reshaping our balance sheet and giving us the financial strength to run our day-to-day operations and the flexibility to seasonal opportunity to develop in the market. As I mentioned, earlier, we remain the king at this housing recovery in several more years of growth in private. And just north of 500,000 new home sales, unit volumes remained 30% below the historic average. And with millennials beginning to buy homes, the leading edge of that demographic is now impacting the market. These factors along with a growing economy, modest wage inflation and a favorable jobs keeps us optimistic about the near and long-term opportunities for PulteGroup.
Let me turn the call over to Bob for more details on our quarterly results. Bob?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Richard, and good morning, everyone. Consistent with Richard's comments regarding the positive market environment, our first quarter financial results shows significant gains in key operating metrics. In addition to delivering strong results for t
componenttext:
Thanks, Richard, and good morning, everyone. Consistent with Richard's comments regarding the positive market environment, our first quarter financial results shows significant gains in key operating metrics. In addition to delivering strong results for the quarter, our Q1 numbers have the company well positioned to deliver outstanding full year results as well.
Looking at the business we appear an excellent demand in the first quarter, with signups increasing 10% to 5,652 homes. The year-over-year increase in the dollar value of signups are even greater, climbing 24% to $2.1 billion.
Breaking down sales buyer group, unit signups increased 2% among first-time buyers and 37% among move-up buyers, while sales decreased 12% with our active adult communities. The decrease among active adult buyers is due in part to the close out of several selling efforts.
Looking at buyer groups, the absorption pace has increased 8% among first-time buyers and declined 4% and 5%, respectively, among new and active adult buyers. Excluding the impact of the [indiscernible] assets, which typically slower absorption basis and largely influenced our move-up buyer group, our overall absorption basis are flat.
During the quarter, home sale revenue has total $1.4 billion, which is up 28% over last year. The significant increase in homebuilding revenues is driven by a 17% increase in closing to 3,945 homes, combined with a 9% increase in average sales price to $353,000. The 17% increase in closings resulted from increased sales activity we've experienced over the last few quarters, coupled with a slight increase in our conversion rate.
Our Q1 conversion rate improved over last year, but it's still running below recent multiyear averages. We expect this pattern to continue in Q2 and throughout 2015 as we make gradual progress on conversion rate versus last year. However, along -- elongated construction cycle times will present us in the near term for reaching the levels we realized a few years ago.
Looking at the mix of our closings in the first quarter,, 29% for first-time buyers, 41% for move-up buyers and 30% were active adult buyers. In Q1 of last year, closing by buyers [indiscernible] for 33% first-time, 34% move-up and 33% active adult.
As I noted, our ASP increased 9% in the first quarter,, reflecting our continued mid-shift towards the move out business, coupled with increases from all consumer groups including an 8% increase to $252,000 for first-time buyers, a 7% increase to $425,000 for move-up buyers and a 5% increase to $353,000 for active adult buyers.
I would like to point out that in addition to the increase in selling prices we realized from our Q1 closings, we also realized notably higher sales prices from current sales that have resulted in the ASP and our backlog being at 14% over the prior year. These gains are primarily driven by the mixed shifts to move-up that I mentioned a moment ago, coupled with higher sales prices at midland communities.
Given our existing -- given our expectations for backlog conversion rates and the longer build time associated with the larger of wheel and products, the higher backlog ASPs will translated the higher closing prices on a gradual plus sustained basis over the remaining quarters of 2016 and into 2017.
In the first quarter, we reported gross margines of 21.9%, which includes approximately 80 basis points of decrease associated with our acquisition of the Wieland assets. Excluding the impact of the Wieland transaction, margins were consistent with last year. It's worth noting that in addition to the impact of the Wieland purchase, our Q1 margins reflected anticipated higher land, labor and material cost, offset by lower interest rates.
Offsetting some of the cost pressure has been our continuous success and systematically increasing the amount of option dollars and lot premioums, which provide better margins we realize in each home. In the first quarter, option revenues per closing inc erased 6% or slightly more than $3,000 over the prior year. While last premiums increased by 4% or just under $600 per home.
Sales discount in the quarter increased 40 basis points over last year to 2.6% per home, which is consistent with results we've seen over the past several quarters. I'd like to take a couple of minutes to address some questions we've got over the past few quarters related to our gross margins. Specifically, over time, we've been asked about the influence on our gross margins of longer-dated assets that has based these adjustments during the downturn in the market. In response to this, you may recall that we provided an analysis of our Del Webb assets and related margins, which was included on Slide 11 in our webcast deck, that provide a comparisons of our older much larger legacy Del Webb community to our smaller newer position. As you can see on that slide, we enjoy strong margins on that entire book of the business with a more recent investment also enjoying strong returns.
Based on continuing questions for investors aroudn our entire land position, we prepared for additional analysis which is included in Slide 12 of the deck. That slide provides details comparing the margins and income statement impact of our newer and never-impaired land, with that of our land that was easily impaired by us or adjusted to the fair value process [indiscernible] acquisition.
Looking at the slide, there are a few things I would like to highlight. First, if you look at the bottom row of the chart, you will see that the legacy lots are actually detrimental to our margins in 2011 through 2013. This is due to the fact that our impairments has fair value process due typically resulted and gross margins in the low teens. There is only after the benefit of several years of ASP growth that closings on those lots represent a slight benefit to our performance.
As with any legacy lot, the margin profile improves over time, assuming their home selling prices are increasing even modestly each year. Second, if you look at the second row of the chart, you will see, as the legacy lots are decreased as a percentage of our overall close. In fact, closings on legacy lots represents 72% of our total closings in 2011, but it falls to 38% in 2015 that will drop even further in 2016 and the years beyond.
And finally, I would highlight the margins on our unimpaired land versus remain almost inside our legacy position reflected the benefit that the invested discipline with 2 [Pulte Homes] as part of our value creation.
Given the margin profile of our total land portfolio and our ongoing Value Creation initiatives, we continue to target gross margins in the range of 21.5% to 22% for the full year.
Moving past gross margins, our SG&A in the first quarter was $191 million or 13.7% of home sale revenues compared with $161 million last year or 14.8% of home sale revenues. The increase in our total lend -- increase our total spend due primarily to the hiring of additional field resources to manage a 41% increase in the number of homes we have under production plus approximately $4 million of charges associated with the Weiland acquisition.
Given that Q1 is a seasonal low point for our deliveries, SG&A spend will certainly decrease as the percentage of revenues over the course of the year, but we also expect the dollar spend wil gradually trend lower in subsequent quarters. As such, we expect full year SG&A spend of approximately $730 million or approximately 10% of home sale revenues.
Turning to financial services. First quarter pretax reported income was $10 million, which compares of $5 million last year. The increase is due primarily to the higher closing volumes generated through our homebuilding operations. Our capture rate for the period was 81% compared to 82% last year.
Looking at our income taxes, our first quarter expense of $35 million, represents that effective tax rate is 29.5%, which is below our guidance of 38%. During the quarter the company realized approximately $10 million of net favorable adjustment relating to the settlement of certain state tax matters. Going forward, we expect our normalized rate to the remaining quarters in 2016 to be consistent with our previous guidance of 38%.
Closing up on the income statement, our Q1 net income was $83 million or $0.24 per share compared to the prior year net income of $55 million or $0.15 per share. $83 million is our highest recorded first quarter net income in a decade, providing further confirmation that we've got off with a very good start for the year.
Looking at our controlled lot position, we improved approximately 7,000 lots for purchase in the first quarter, which represents an average of roughly 160 lots per community approved. We continue to focus on smaller and faster turning communities. However, given that most of the land position we're putting under control are raw, we still estimate it will take 12 to 18 months before a community will typically com online. At quarter-end, we had approximately 146,000 lots under control, of which 30% were controlled via option.
During the quarter, we spent $262 million on land acquisition, which does not include our purchase of the Wieland asset. Based on our Q1 land acquisition spend, we're on track with our prior guidance of investing approximately $1.2 billion excluding Wieland for land acquisition in 2016. This estimate assumes we can continue to identify projects that could be in our disciplined underwriting guidelines and return thresholds.
Consistent with our Value Creation priorities, we continue to return funds to shareholders through dividend and share repurchases. After curtailing stock purchases in Q4 2015 because of activities surrounding the Wieland transaction, we reinstated our buyback programs that [indiscernible] be a consistent and systematic participant market for our shares. During the quarter, we repurchased 3.1 million shares for $50 million or $16.36 per share. We ended the quarter with $1 billion of cash, which includes funds raised through our February senior note offering. We plan to use approximately $465 million of our cash to reture bond, which will mature in May of this year. Our debt total capital ratio at quarter-end was 39% compared with 30% at the end of 2015. On a proforma basis, adjusting for the month, the May bond repayment, our debt-to-capital ratio cost to 35%.
For the quarter, we operated from 709 communities, which is up [ph] 15% in the same period last year. The increase is higher than our guidance range of 8% to 10%, but reflects the slower closeout rate for existing communities as opposed to an acceleration of new store openings. As such, we expect the year-over-year change in community count will come back in line with our previous guidance as we move through the year.
And finally, our quarter end backlog of 8,755 homes is valued at $3.4 billion, which represent an increases of 15% and 31%, respectively, over the prior year.
Now, let me turn the call over to Ryan Marshall for some additional comments.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob, and good morning. As both Richard and Bob has mentioned this morning, our financial results demonstrate the 2016 is shaping up to be an inflection point for the company. Reflective of actions we have taken over the past several years, we've t
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob, and good morning. As both Richard and Bob has mentioned this morning, our financial results demonstrate the 2016 is shaping up to be an inflection point for the company. Reflective of actions we have taken over the past several years, we've transitioned the business to deliver more growth but without introducing excess risk. For the past 5-plus years, we've been methodically altering our risk profile by selling off unproductive land partials and moving through long lined assets that have been a drag on the balance sheet. Over the same period, we have reinvested in shorter duration, high-margin communities that have generated high returns and driven the financial gains in the past few years.
Having been in the field for over a decade, I'm now part of the senior leadership team for the past few years, I fully appreciate the change we've undergone in pursuing the Value Creation strategy and the benefits we've captured.
As we transition to responsible growth, my focus is on ensuring we capture additional operating efficiencies while continuing our disciplined investment process. This means delivering more volume and a profitable, responsible and risk-adjusted way, and avoiding the trap of chasing growth for growth's sake.
During my field visits, I have and will continue to drive on the point that we are running a business designed to deliver true cycle returns, and this demand is efficiently growing pretax income while intelligently investing in the business.
Now looking at our homebuilding operations, we've had 7,909 homes under construction at the end of the quarter, of which 27% were stuck. Consistent  with our previous guidance, we purposely increased production heading into the spring selling season and help manage and smooth our overall production cadence.
The speck sales tracking the plan and finish by continuing to average well below 1 per community, we are right where we wanted to be during this busy time of the Spring selling season. After several months of strong spec starts, and now having a large and growing backlog of sold homes, we have already started reducing the number of specs we put into production.
Looking at demand conditions for the quarter, we are very pleased with activity in a marketplace these past few months. As you might expect, with a 10% increase in signups in the period, we generally saw a positive traffic and demand conditions across the country during the quarter. And I would add that this trend has continued into the first few weeks of April.
In summary, the feedback I've received from our operators during my recent market visits is consistent with what we've seen in the data. The selling season has gotten off to a very good start. Taking this down to a regional level, on the East Coast, overall demand was solid in the quarter and got better as you move from North and South. Consistent with the trend over the last several quarters, we continue to see stronger demand in the Carolinas, Georgia and Florida. We are excited about the long-term opportunities we see in the South, particularly in the Southeast given the migration trends, higher preferences in land availability. It is one of the reasons why were interested in the Wieland assets.
Looking at the middle third [ph] of the country, we saw broad-based improvement in demand through the Midwest.
With sign climbing over 30% for the quarter, winter weather conditions were a little easier at the start of this year compared with 2015, but we are optimistic that the higher signups for the quarter reflect a more fundamental improvement in demand. Dropping down into Texas on a year-over-year basis, signups were essentially flat as exceptional strength in Dallas was offset by softer demand in Houston and San Antonio. Houston demand improved as we move through the quarter, and the market has performed better than, I think, many were expecting.
And finally, looking out to our west markets. We continue to experience good demand, particularly in some of our bigger markets including Northern California, Phoenix and Las Vegas. We have some new communities open in Las Vegas and it is great to see the market responding favorably to these new locations.
Given the differences on market dynamics that can exist in the local level, that can be tough to generalize. But we would say to demand continued to improve and the communities located closer to city center fair better in terms of sales, prices and pages.
The inventory of homes available for sale remains tight in most of our markets. And at least on the new home side, will likely remain that way for a while given the limited supply of finished lots available. I have already met some of you at conferences earlier this year, and I look forward to meeting more of you as the year progresses. Let me turn the call back over to Richard. Richard?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ryan. In summary, we had an excellent quarter. And given our strong backlog and growing production pipeline are well positioned at an excellent year. The work we have done since value creation began in 2011 has responsibly positioned PulteGroup to
componenttext:
Thanks, Ryan. In summary, we had an excellent quarter. And given our strong backlog and growing production pipeline are well positioned at an excellent year. The work we have done since value creation began in 2011 has responsibly positioned PulteGroup to be a true cycle performer, which is why we look forward to the future with optimism.
I want to close by thanking our terrific PulteGroup employees, who despite the public distractions these past few weeks, have and continued to do a fantastic job, staying focused and delivering our customers. You are the best team in the business, and I could not be more proud to work side-by-side with you.
Let me turn the call back to Jim Zeumer. Jim?

componenttext: Susan, it's Richard. The Wieland acquisition is progressing well. The teams are moving through the integration process as expected. So it's early yet, but so far, so good.

componenttext: The first question I had was just going back to the order trends and by component community account of sales pace. I believe, you said that community account was better-than-expected due to lower closeout rates during the quarter, but you expect 2Q to get back to original guidance. I just want to make sure I'm thinking about that right, that the original was for first half community count to be up 8% to 10% versus for 4Q end. And also, from a absorption standpoint, roughly flat year-over-year and I believe you had expected suspected Wieland to maybe have a little bit of a negative impact and a slight overall decline in absorption. It seems flat versus that original slight decline was also related to the slower closeout of the older communities. And could we expect that original expectation to reassert itself in the second quarter, as well?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: A lot there. But I think to answer your first question, yes, your memory is correct. So we were 8% to 10% in Q2, year-over-year, and then 10% to 15% year-over-year in the back half of the year. And what we're saying is we think we'll get back to that rang
componenttext: A lot there. But I think to answer your first question, yes, your memory is correct. So we were 8% to 10% in Q2, year-over-year, and then 10% to 15% year-over-year in the back half of the year. And what we're saying is we think we'll get back to that range of growth period-over-period as to absorption paces. We did say coming into the year that Wieland would likely had an impact on our absorption basis because it moves a little bit slower than our traditional poultry business. And in fact, that's what we saw. So we highlighted that you had an 8% increase in first time, and 4% to 5% decreases in move-up and active-adult. And if you take Wieland out, the net to net 5% down, 8.4% to 8.0% in terms of a [indiscernible] paces. If you take Wieland out, we go up to 8.4%. So essentially, we're flat, x the Wieland business.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Also on the gross margins, a little bit better than we were looking for, but you reiterated your , full year outlook on the net basis. So I just wanted to make sure that we're seeing that seeing wrap the right way in term of the interest amortization, how should we think about that for the year as well as any moving parts that were maybe better-than-expected pre-interest?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, we've given guidance, 21.5% to 22%, we're reiterating that. Coming to the [indiscernible] we have said, Wieland would influence our margins by about 70 basis points for the year. We still think that's a pretty good number. We have given qua
componenttext: Well, I think, we've given guidance, 21.5% to 22%, we're reiterating that. Coming to the [indiscernible] we have said, Wieland would influence our margins by about 70 basis points for the year. We still think that's a pretty good number. We have given quarterly estimates on that and was 100 in the first quarter, 70 in the second, 50 in the third and fourth, and we were a little bit less impactful in the first quarter, it was like 80 basis points, but we think through the year that it's still about 70 basis points. So coming into it, we said, look, we've got higher land and labor construction cost, and that will be offset by interest increases. That's exactly what we signed a first quarter. I think you can expect to continue to see that with the balance of 2016. Again, within that annual range of 21.5% to 22%. Obviously, the financing we did here in the first quarter took our leverage up, took our interest spend up. So for the first time in a long time, our cash spend is a little bit higher than our interest expense. That won't influence 2016, we'll have some influence on '17 and beyond. But I guess the only thing I'd point out to that end is paying down the debt that we'll do in the second quarter, there's a net end of about $500 million year-over-year, that's roughly 5%, 5.5%. So it's not a huge incremental interest increase as we go forward.

We've been quite clear that the majority of our investments have gone to that new web category. So that was the majority of it. There was also a little impact from the Wieland backlog coming in. So you see the backlog ASPs expanding pretty dramatically and that's primarily due to mix with a little bit of Wieland and sum price.

componenttextpreview: John, it's Ryan. We actually saw the Houston market recover, probably better-than-expected, the further that we move through the quarter. The lower price point certainly performed better, and we saw a little bit of slowness in the higher end price points

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Trey on for Steve. So my first question is, on your gross margin in the quarter, you definitely did a lot better than we were looking for, with the deal almost reaching 22%. And we're wondering, how would your yearend margin guidance rema
componenttext: This is actually Trey on for Steve. So my first question is, on your gross margin in the quarter, you definitely did a lot better than we were looking for, with the deal almost reaching 22%. And we're wondering, how would your yearend margin guidance remaining in the 21.5% to 22% range. How you're expecting your quarterly cadence to develop when normally, we would expect lowest gross margin the first quarter and the highest gross margin at the end of the year.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Trey, this is Richard, I'll answer that. We're not providing quarterly margin guidance. We're very pleased with our margins. I think you could take away is that we continue to run the business focused high returns, but margins are holding up and we're ple
componenttext: Trey, this is Richard, I'll answer that. We're not providing quarterly margin guidance. We're very pleased with our margins. I think you could take away is that we continue to run the business focused high returns, but margins are holding up and we're pleased to reiterate the guidance that we started the year with.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So you would expect and obviously, the 21.5% to 22%, that everything would stay within that range for the year [indiscernible]?
componenttext: Okay. So you would expect and obviously, the 21.5% to 22%, that everything would stay within that range for the year [indiscernible]?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: That's our expectation. Yes.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Matthew Bouley on for Mike. I just wanted to ask about the legacy wind beyond what you're planning to deliver. So just how are you thinking about bringing specifically your inactive legacy land back? Have you seen signs that demand is pus
componenttext: This is actually Matthew Bouley on for Mike. I just wanted to ask about the legacy wind beyond what you're planning to deliver. So just how are you thinking about bringing specifically your inactive legacy land back? Have you seen signs that demand is pushing out a bit into outer locations? And then how should we think about potential margins impacts from that? For example, would there be any more interest capitalized into the older land?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to the final question, the answer is, no, the interest doesn't get capitalized into older positions that way. But I guess the way I would answer that is, we don't have a tremendous amount of, what I would characterize as out-of-the-ring assets. If yo
componenttext: Just to the final question, the answer is, no, the interest doesn't get capitalized into older positions that way. But I guess the way I would answer that is, we don't have a tremendous amount of, what I would characterize as out-of-the-ring assets. If you think back, we'd be certainly have a large lot position associated with in some of the larger older Del Webb position, it's that Slide 11 in the deck. And we've talked about that for years, that it would just take us time to work through that. Good news is strong margins [indiscernible] good return on incremental investment. We own the land and now we're just -- development dollars, sticks and bricks. So we do okay on that. It's also worth mentioning that over the last, gosh, I guess, it's 5 years now, we been pretty active in selling some of those older, what I would characterize as challenged assets. So you think that over the last [ph] 45 years, it's certainly more than $400 million, probably of land sales that moved a lot of those, again, what I'd characterize as challenged assets. So our book today doesn't have a lot of that.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. Got you. And then secondly, just on SG&A, I was wondering if you can elaborate a little bit on the workforce investments that you mentioned. So just geographies and which types of labor were you targeting?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Matthew, this is Richard. Primarily, that's field resources to get home some production field managers or superintendents that manage our business. We've had a very large increase in home side of production, 41%, and that takes incremental people to
componenttext: Yes, Matthew, this is Richard. Primarily, that's field resources to get home some production field managers or superintendents that manage our business. We've had a very large increase in home side of production, 41%, and that takes incremental people to help manage the process, and most of it was related to construction resources to get those homes into production for deliveries later this year. And geography agnostic, we've had a fairly significant ramp up in land spend over the past few years. And as we've indicated, 2016 would be a pivot year for volume for the company and you're beginning to see that come through the system, and that's what those dollars are for.

componenttext: Yes, this is Richard. I'll take that one. We are not. We're seeing good activity on a higher price points around the system. Again, we have a modest number of really high priced point homes, $600,000, $700,000, $800,000 relative to our ASPs in the mid to high 3s overall, but we're seeing good demand. And most of that, for us, is in Northern California, some in D.C., excuse me, some of the higher priced markets in general. But overall, some parts are good in that area.

componenttext: [indiscernible] for Steven [indiscernible]. First, You mentioned that Del Webb, both quarters were down on the community closeouts, I was wondering if you have heard anything from the field though about equity market volatility and negatively impacting that buyer.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Ryan. We've seen a little bit of traffic slowdown in our Del Webb communities, which we think this is directly related to the market volatility. We saw that lesson as we move through the quarter, and some of the market volatility started to
componenttext: Paul, this is Ryan. We've seen a little bit of traffic slowdown in our Del Webb communities, which we think this is directly related to the market volatility. We saw that lesson as we move through the quarter, and some of the market volatility started to come back in the normal ranges. We're quite pleased with what we're seeing out of our Del Webb markets right now.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then you spoke to Houston, improving through for the quarter but now, Houston has its own weather problem. What kind of impact do you think that would have on 2Q conversion rates? And then how long after we have a significant weather event like
componenttext: Okay. And then you spoke to Houston, improving through for the quarter but now, Houston has its own weather problem. What kind of impact do you think that would have on 2Q conversion rates? And then how long after we have a significant weather event like that? Does it take demand to rebound?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, great question. Houston's, obviously, dealing with some weather challenges right now. We haven't gotten a full assessment of the extent of the damage. Many of the communities are still underwater and have a struggle getting out of their homes. We don
componenttext: Yes, great question. Houston's, obviously, dealing with some weather challenges right now. We haven't gotten a full assessment of the extent of the damage. Many of the communities are still underwater and have a struggle getting out of their homes. We don't expect it to have much of an impact at all on our Q2, probably, it's fairly small impact as we move into Q3.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Paul, just to add to that, remember, Houston's roughly 4% or 5% of our total company volume. So if you had it collectively, obviously, we're paying attention to it, bought were not too concerned about it. And we do still have 7, 8 months to watch that
componenttext: And Paul, just to add to that, remember, Houston's roughly 4% or 5% of our total company volume. So if you had it collectively, obviously, we're paying attention to it, bought were not too concerned about it. And we do still have 7, 8 months to watch that for the year.

componenttext: The first question, looking at some of the regions, Northeast down a bit more than the last year. Strong Midwest, strong Southeast. Relative to absorption, is it okay to think that's generally sort of moving in line with the community count or is there any more [indiscernible] demands in any of those sort of outside new regions in the quarter from an order perspective?

componenttext: Jack, we're seeing the West, our Western markets do quite well. We think this is reflective of some of the places where the local economies are strong as well as where we have great investment. We've also seen the Midwest perform very well year-over-year. So those are the 2 spots that I would highlight.

componenttextpreview: Okay. And then another follow-up on G&A guidance on the dollar. I think, Richard, you said a lot of that is field-type labor. Is the significant improvement or applied improvement in G&A ratio due to the end of the year, is that more a function of sort of
componenttext: Okay. And then another follow-up on G&A guidance on the dollar. I think, Richard, you said a lot of that is field-type labor. Is the significant improvement or applied improvement in G&A ratio due to the end of the year, is that more a function of sort of flexing the overhead spend around the construction and then maybe bringing that back down? Or is it all conversion rate improvement? Or is it sort of a mix?

componenttext: I'll speak to the first part of that and maybe I'll ask Bob to comment a little bit more. From an overall perspective, we're definitely going to get a conversion rate improvement as we move through the years. You might expect with all the homes in production, that will be flowing through. There is also, however, a little bit of a dollar, total dollar improvement, maybe Bob can speak to that.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016

componenttext: Yes. We've talked about this in the past and for the most part, our dollar spent is relatively fixed. We don't run sales commissions through SG&A, and so we have other than production level and footprint expansions. So we're hoping a bunch of new communities there costs associated with that. So as we look at the balance of the year, the guidance was implied another $540 million of spend, which translates to about $180 million a quarter, and I was just that's kind of I will spend it. It's not going to be largely variable.

componenttext: In terms of going back to [indiscernible] a couple different ways, variance is in the gross margin expectations, can you talk about how your expectations for lumber inflation as well as labor inflation, with again, a gross margin implication have moved since you reported in your last quarter.

componenttextpreview: Yes, with that coming into the year, that was a relatively benign commodity market but a relatively right labor market that we saw our construction cost up about 2%, and that was largely labor, we still see that. We've got pretty good visibility into 6 mo
componenttext: Yes, with that coming into the year, that was a relatively benign commodity market but a relatively right labor market that we saw our construction cost up about 2%, and that was largely labor, we still see that. We've got pretty good visibility into 6 months of cost. And so in terms of our backlog, we have like I said, pretty good visibility into our cost structures, is going to be on that. So we have seen that move materially since with that thought.

componenttext: Understood. And then just 1 follow-up, it is the backlog conversion. What's your confidence level going into kind of the peak production season for closings in the second and third quarter, and you don't have anymore account disruption or [indiscernible] expect [indiscernible]. Can you talk about some other preventive actions you're going to take and to improve that confidence level?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, will, this is Richard. I'll take that. Certainly, [indiscernible] is definitely helpful to us. We've also paid a lot of attention to the overall labor market in total when we saw some of the disruption last year, and ahve done our best to add increme
componenttext: Yes, will, this is Richard. I'll take that. Certainly, [indiscernible] is definitely helpful to us. We've also paid a lot of attention to the overall labor market in total when we saw some of the disruption last year, and ahve done our best to add incremental vendors where we could overall. So we're pleased with the progress we've made. And just to be clear, Bob mentioned this earlier on the answer to your question, we expect improvement relative to prior-year conversion rates, but not back to old historical levels. And that's primarily due to the fact that our cycle times are expanded. We indicated on one of our calls last year that they were up 8 or 9 days in total, and we're are still seeing that. So we're just -- we've improved our processes overall, but we're not expecting to get back into historical ranges even though we will be improving relative to prior year.

componenttext: Slide 12, very interesting. I have 2 questions. Related to this slide, what can we infer from the outlook, I guess. How do you guys kind of balance where you think if you're talking about gross margin, which we can see on the non-adjusted side having peaked in '14, could you kind of talk about the [indiscernible] that are associated in each of those pre-interest. I mean, do you have higher interest expense in the legacy? Or is there any accounting nuances that we should be familiar with there if we think about the mix aging 3x if you complete those legacy land positions.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, fair question. The answer is no. Our interest gets applied across our entire production portfolio. And so when we manage the business, these are the numbers we're managing again. So this is sort of book value historical cost versus selling price for
componenttext: Ken, fair question. The answer is no. Our interest gets applied across our entire production portfolio. And so when we manage the business, these are the numbers we're managing again. So this is sort of book value historical cost versus selling price for each. So as you look at this, interest it doesn't really influence it.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ken, this is Richard, I would just add, I think what you should take away is that the investments we've made the past 4 or 5 years are at really nice margins. We're very pleased with that. And that even though what we declining as a total percentage o
componenttext: And Ken, this is Richard, I would just add, I think what you should take away is that the investments we've made the past 4 or 5 years are at really nice margins. We're very pleased with that. And that even though what we declining as a total percentage of total production, the legacy lots will continue to be a tailwind for margins going forward. Those are 2 key points we're trying to drive here.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. I think you guys did very well by presenting it this way. My next question is a bit more regional. Specifically, about California. It's not the biggest market for you guys, but could you talk about the trends you're seeing in San Francisco giv
componenttext: Understood. I think you guys did very well by presenting it this way. My next question is a bit more regional. Specifically, about California. It's not the biggest market for you guys, but could you talk about the trends you're seeing in San Francisco given perhaps slow downs we're seeing in VC funding and how that might impact from your points that you; have in San Francisco. And if you could describe in a rate of foreign buyers, if that's an item that you have been tracking in California, in Seattle, in general.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ken, this is Ryan. We've actually seen exceptional strength in our Northern California market and it's really reflective of the wonderful investments that we've made. Really focused on the core employment areas in the East and South bay. We've got a lot o
componenttext: Ken, this is Ryan. We've actually seen exceptional strength in our Northern California market and it's really reflective of the wonderful investments that we've made. Really focused on the core employment areas in the East and South bay. We've got a lot of infill opportunities and infill communities that we've invested in, and we're seeing excellent demand that is being driven by what's been a strong labor market as well as very tight supply. So we're, obviously, watching some of the things that are going on in the technology sector, but we stayed away from some of the outer locations as you move further away from the Bay Area. We think those are some of those areas that will, obviously, be hit first if the labor market there tightens.

componenttext: This is actually Michael [indiscernible] for Bob this morning. I just had a question about the pace of ASP growth and your order growth, they both were very strong. I'm just wondering, how much of this is attributable to community township? And how much will go to price appreciation?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, mike, this is Richard. The majority of it is the continued mixed shift that we've had in a business. ASP is arising strongly because of our investment of the past couple of years with mixed shift. We are also getting some benefit out of the Wieland b
componenttext: Yes, mike, this is Richard. The majority of it is the continued mixed shift that we've had in a business. ASP is arising strongly because of our investment of the past couple of years with mixed shift. We are also getting some benefit out of the Wieland business, integrating into our backlog which raises our ASP some, but the vast majority of it is from our core business continuing to move higher. So as you know, our ASP in backlog is over $380,000 now. And as Bob indicated, we'll be delivering into the number slowly and steadily through this year and into next.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then when we talk about the delayed closure of some community accounts, are any of the significantly higher or lower price points that would cause fluctuation quarter-over-quarter as we look forward into the rest of the year as those close out.
componenttext: Great. And then when we talk about the delayed closure of some community accounts, are any of the significantly higher or lower price points that would cause fluctuation quarter-over-quarter as we look forward into the rest of the year as those close out.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. This is Richard, again. No. And this is one of the reasons we don't log community account as a metric. We explained this before. You might have a handful of legacy communities that had 1 or 2 sales that drifted into -- from Q4 into Q1, and those get
componenttext: Yes. This is Richard, again. No. And this is one of the reasons we don't log community account as a metric. We explained this before. You might have a handful of legacy communities that had 1 or 2 sales that drifted into -- from Q4 into Q1, and those get counted as a an inconvenience -- excuse me, a community in our convention. So no, there's no significant impact on either ASPs or anything else related to the few close out communities that we have some activity in Q1.

componenttext: Good morning. My name is Carol, and I will be a conference operator today. At this time, I would like welcome everyone to the Q1 2016 PulteGroup, Inc. Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn today's call over to Mr. Jim Zeumer.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Carol, and let me welcome everyone to today's conference call discussing PulteGroup's first quarter financial results for the 3 months ended March 31, 2016. And joining me for today's call are Richard Dugas, Chairman and CEO; Ryan Marsha
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Carol, and let me welcome everyone to today's conference call discussing PulteGroup's first quarter financial results for the 3 months ended March 31, 2016. And joining me for today's call are Richard Dugas, Chairman and CEO; Ryan Marshall, President; Bob O'shaughnessy, Executive Vice President and CFO; Jim Ossowski, Vice President, Finance, and Controller. 
A copy of this morning's earnings release and the presentation slides that accompanies today's call have been posted to our corporate website at pultegroupinc.com. We'll also post an audio replay of today's call later this afternoon.
Before we begin the discussion, I want to alert everyone, all the participants, that today's presentation may include forward-looking statements about PulteGroup's future performance. Actual results could differ materially from those suggested by our comments made today. The most significant risk factors that could affect future results are summarized as part of today's earnings release and within the accompanying presentation slides. These risk factors and other key information are detailed in our SEC filings, including our annual and quarterly reports.
Now let me turn the call over to Richard Dugas. Richard?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim, and good morning, everyone. Some of you may have seen the letter issued yesterday by Bill Pulte over his grandson's performance on CNBC yesterday. As there is nothing new in Bill's letter, we will not be responding to these attacks or otherwi
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim, and good morning, everyone. Some of you may have seen the letter issued yesterday by Bill Pulte over his grandson's performance on CNBC yesterday. As there is nothing new in Bill's letter, we will not be responding to these attacks or otherwise be discussing the Pultes on this call, other than to say that we stand by the completeness and accuracy of our previous disclosures. We run this company for the benefit of all shareholders, and we'll continue to do so. I've had opportunity these past few weeks to speak with many of our largest holders, and it's encouraging to hear your support for our entire leadership team, our Board of Directors and our Value Creation strategy. I want to take this opportunity to ensure all investors we are busy running this company and remain squarely focused on continuing to deliver value for you.
To that point, we were extremely pleased with the strength of our first quarter results. Consistent with our strategy and our efforts to enhance returns on invested capital, for the past few years, we have highlighted strategic pricing, construction productivity and balance sheet efficiency as drivers of our performance. Our financial results over the past few years reflect these drivers as we realized significant gains in pretax profitability despite only modest gains in production volumes.
Many of you have seen the graph in our investor presentation, which we included in today's conference call slides, which shows our pretax income improving by $1.1 billion over the past 5 years on just a 12% increase in closings. We have communicated that 2016 would be an inflection year with increasing volume being delivered to [ph] a much more efficient homebuilding operation. The combination of rising unit volumes, increasing average sales prices and a more efficient homebuilding machine can translate into significant earnings growth. Add in the benefit of consistently returning funds to shareholders, and you have a business that can produce high returns for its investors over time.
As Bob will detail in a moment, the business is beginning to turn in that direction with signups increased by 10% to almost 5,700 homes, closing volumes gaining 17% to almost 4,000 closings, average selling prices expanding by 9% to $353,000 and our backlog value climbing 31% to $3.4 billion. These metrics, obviously, resulted in the strong quarterly performance in the first quarter. But equally important, they position the company to deliver continued growth over the balance of 2016.
While our Q1 numbers and our expectations for 2016 point to increasing scale, we have not and will not lose our focus on our primary objective: to run a business that can deliver better returns over the housing cycle and do so with less risk. We have believed since the outset of this housing recovery that it would be more gradual than the V-shaped rebound typical of most housing cycles. Our thesis is unchanged as we expect an extended recovery will continue to unfold for the next several years supported by an improving economy, favorable demographics, years of relative underbuilding and a supportive mortgage rate environment.
Given these dynamics, we have been increasing our investment in the business but have done so in a disciplined manner by emphasizing smaller projects while expanding our use of options when possible. This has served to shorten our years of land supply, helping to mitigate market risk. We have also focused our land investments on closer relocations where we think demand is more sustainable when the market ultimately takes a breather. We have excepted a trade-off of having to pay a little more for certain positions on where we can be more confident in their future performance.
As evidence of our focus on driving returns and reducing risk relative to prior business practices, consider that our supply of owned lots has fallen from approximately 8.5 years in 2010 to roughly 5.5 years in 2015. Based on our land acquisition discipline, expected sales paces, as we work through some of our longer and older communities, we look forward -- excuse me, we look for our own supply to continue trending lower in the future. Among the reasons for the decline is that approved land deals over the past 5 years have averaged roughly 125 controlled lots per community, and this includes 31 new Del Webb projects over that time frame that have averaged just over 500 controlled lots each.
Along with how we manage land, our more disciplined approach to the business extends to the management of the company's entire balance sheet. Bob and his team have done an outstanding job reshaping our balance sheet and giving us the financial strength to run our day-to-day operations and the flexibility to seize on opportunities that develop in the market. As I mentioned, earlier, we remain [indiscernible] that this housing recovery has several more years of growth in front of it. At just north of 500,000 new home sales, unit volumes remain 30% below the historic average. And with millennials beginning to buy homes, the leading edge of that demographic is now impacting the market. These factors, along with a growing economy, modest wage inflation and a favorable outlook for jobs, keeps us optimistic about the near- and long-term opportunities for PulteGroup.
Let me turn over the call to Bob for more details on our quarterly results. Bob?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Richard, and good morning, everyone. Consistent with Richard's comments regarding the positive market environment, our first quarter financial results show significant gains in key operating metrics. In addition to delivering strong results in the
componenttext:
Thanks, Richard, and good morning, everyone. Consistent with Richard's comments regarding the positive market environment, our first quarter financial results show significant gains in key operating metrics. In addition to delivering strong results in the quarter, our Q1 numbers have the company well positioned to deliver outstanding full year results as well.
Looking at the business, we experienced excellent demand in the first quarter with signups increasing 10% to 5,652 homes. The year-over-year increase in the dollar value of signups was even greater, climbing 24% to $2.1 billion.
Breaking down sales by buyer group, unit signups increased 2% among first-time buyers and 37% among move-up buyers, while sales decreased 12% with our active adult communities. The decrease among active adult buyers was due in part to the close-out of several selling efforts.
Looking at buyer groups, absorption pace has increased 8% among first-time buyers and declined 4% and 5%, respectively, among move-up and active adult buyers. Excluding the impact of the Wieland assets, which typically had slower absorption paces and largely influenced our move-up buyer group, our overall absorption paces were flat.
During the quarter, home sale revenues totaled $1.4 billion, which is up 28% over last year. The significant increase in homebuilding revenues was driven by a 17% increase in closing to 3,945 homes combined with a 9% increase in average sales price to $353,000. The 17% increase in closings resulted from the increased sales activity we've experienced over the last few quarters, coupled with a slight increase in our conversion rate. Our Q1 conversion rate improved over last year but is still running below recent multiyear averages. We expect this pattern to continue in Q2 and throughout 2015 as we make gradual progress on conversion rates versus last year. However, elongated construction cycle times will present (sic) [ prevent ] us in the near term from reaching the levels we realized a few years ago.
Looking at the mix of our closings in the first quarter. 29% were first-time buyers, 41% were move-up buyers and 30% were active adult buyers. In Q1 of last year, closings by buyer group were 33% first-time, 34% move-up and 33% active adult.
As I noted, our ASP increased 9% in the first quarter, reflecting our continuing mix shift towards the move-up business, coupled with increases from all consumer groups, including an 8% increase to $252,000 for first-time buyers, a 7% increase to $425,000 for move-up buyers and a 5% increase to $353,000 for active adult buyers.
I would like to point out that in addition to the  increased selling prices we realized from our Q1 closings, we also realized notably higher sales prices from current sales that resulted in the ASP and our backlog being at 14% over the prior year. These pricing gains are primarily driven by the mix shift to move-up that I mentioned a moment ago, coupled with higher sales prices at Wieland communities.
Given our existing -- given our expectations for backlog conversion rates and the longer build times associated with the larger Wieland product, the higher-backlog ASPs will translate into higher closing prices on a gradual but sustained basis over the remaining quarters of 2016 and into 2017.
In the first quarter, we reported gross margins of 21.9%, which includes approximately 80 basis points of decrease associated with our acquisition of the Wieland assets. Excluding the impact of the Wieland transaction, margins were consistent with last year. It's worth noting that in addition to the impact of the Wieland purchase, our Q1 margins reflected anticipated higher land, labor and material costs, offset by lower interest charges.
Offsetting some of the cost pressure has been our continued success in systematically increasing the amount of option dollars and lot premiums, which provide richer margins we realize on each home. In the first quarter, option revenues per closing increased 6% or slightly more than $3,000 over the prior year while lot premiums increased by 4% or just under $600 per home.
Sales discounts in the quarter increased 40 basis points over last year to 2.6% per home, which is consistent with the results we've seen over the past several quarters. 
I'd like to take a couple of minutes to address some questions we've gotten over the past few quarters related to our gross margins. Specifically, over time, we've been asked about the influence on our gross margins of longer-dated assets that had basis [ph] adjustments during the downturn in the market. In response to this, you may recall that we provided an analysis of our Del Webb assets and related margins, which was included on Slide 11 in our webcast deck, that provided comparisons of our older, much larger legacy Del Webb communities to our smaller, newer positions. As you can see on that slide, we enjoy strong margins on that entire book of business with the more recent investments also enjoying strong returns.
Based on continuing questions from investors around our entire land position, we prepared some additional analysis, which is included in Slide 12 of the deck. That slide provides details comparing the margins and income statement impacts of our newer and never-impaired land with that of our land that was either impaired by us or adjusted through the fair value process as part of the Centex  acquisition.
Looking at the slide, there are a few things I would like to highlight. First, if you look at the bottom row of the chart, you will see that the legacy lots were actually detrimental to our margins in 2011 through 2013. This was due to the fact that our impairments and fair value processes typically resulted in gross margins in the low teens. It was only after the benefit that took several years of ASP growth that closings on those lots represent a slight benefit to our performance.
As with any legacy lot, the margin profile improves over time, assuming that home selling prices are increasing even modestly each year. 
Second, if you look at the second row of the chart, you will see that the legacy lots are decreasing as a percentage of our overall closings. In fact, closings on legacy lots represented 72% of our total closings in 2011, but it falls to 38% in 2015 and will drop even further in 2016 and the years beyond.
And finally, I would highlight the margins on our unimpaired land purchases remain almost the size of our legacy positions, reflecting the benefits of the investment discipline we instituted as part of Value Creation.
Given the margin profile of our total land portfolio and our ongoing Value Creation initiatives, we continue to target gross margins in the range of 21.5% to 22% for the full year.
Moving past gross margins, our SG&A in the first quarter was $191 million or 13.7% of home sale revenues compared with $161 million last year or 14.8% of home sale revenues. The increase in our total land -- the increase in our total spend was due primarily to the hiring of additional field resources to manage a 41% increase in the number of homes we have under production, plus approximately $4 million of charges associated with the Wieland acquisition. Given that Q1 is the seasonal low point for our deliveries, SG&A spend will certainly decrease as a percentage of revenues over the course of the year, but we also expect the dollar spend will gradually trend lower in subsequent quarters. As such, we expect full year SG&A spend of approximately $730 million or approximately 10% of home sale revenues.
Turning to financial services. First quarter pretax reported income was $10 million, which compares with $5 million last year. The increase was due primarily to the higher closing volumes generated through our homebuilding operations. Our capture rate for the period was 81% compared with 82% last year.
Looking at our income taxes. Our first quarter expense of $35 million represents an effective tax rate of 29.5%, which was below our guidance of 38%. During the quarter the company realized approximately $10 million of net favorable adjustments relating to the settlement of certain state tax matters. Going forward, we expect our normalized rate for the remaining quarters in 2016 to be consistent with our previous guidance of 38%.
Finishing up on the income statement, our Q1 net income was $83 million or $0.24 per share compared with prior year net income of $55 million or $0.15 per share. $83 million is our highest reported first quarter net income in a decade, providing further confirmation that we've gotten off to a very good start for the year.
Looking at our controlled lot position. We approved approximately 7,000 lots for purchase in the first quarter, which represents an average of roughly 160 lots per community approved. We continue to focus on smaller, faster-turning communities. However, given that most of the land positions we're putting under control are raw, we still estimate it will take 12 to 18 months before a community will typically come online. At quarter-end, we had approximately 146,000 lots under control, of which 30% were controlled via option.
During the quarter, we spent $262 million on land acquisition, which does not include our purchase of the Wieland assets. Based on our Q1 land acquisition spend, we're on track with our prior guidance of investing approximately $1.2 billion, excluding Wieland, for land acquisition in 2016. This estimate assumes we can continue to identify projects that meet our disciplined underwriting guidelines and return thresholds.
Consistent with our Value Creation priorities, we continue to return funds to shareholders through dividends and share repurchases. After curtailing stock repurchases in Q4 2015 because of activities surrounding the Wieland transaction, we reinstated our buyback programs and look to be a consistent and systematic participant in the market for our shares. During the quarter, we repurchased 3.1 million shares for $50 million or $16.36 per share. 
We ended the quarter with $1 billion of cash, which includes funds raised through our February senior note offering. We plan to use approximately $465 million of our cash to retire bonds, which will mature in May of this year. 
Our debt-to-total capital ratio at quarter-end was 39% compared with 30% at the end of 2015. On a proforma basis, adjusting for the month of May bond repayment, our debt-to-capital ratio drops to 35%.
For the quarter, we operated from 709 communities, which is up 16% from the same period last year. The increase is higher than our guidance range of 8% to 10% but reflects the slower close-out rate for existing communities as opposed to an acceleration of new store openings. As such, we expect the year-over-year change in community count will come back in line with our previous guidance as we move through the year.
And finally, our quarter-end backlog of 8,755 homes is valued at $3.4 billion, which represent increases of 15% and 31%, respectively, over the prior year.
Now let me turn the call over to Ryan Marshall for some additional comments.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob, and good morning. As both Richard and Bob have mentioned this morning, our financial results demonstrate that 2016 is shaping up to be an inflection point for the company. Reflective of actions we have taken over the past several years, we've
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob, and good morning. As both Richard and Bob have mentioned this morning, our financial results demonstrate that 2016 is shaping up to be an inflection point for the company. Reflective of actions we have taken over the past several years, we've transitioned the business to deliver more growth but without introducing excess risk. For the past 5-plus years, we've been methodically altering our risk profile by selling off unproductive land parcels and moving through long-lived assets that have been a drag on the balance sheet. Over the same period, we've reinvested in shorter duration, high-margin communities that have generated high returns and driven the financial gains of the past few years.
Having been in the field for over a decade and now part of the senior leadership team for the past few years, I fully appreciate the change we've undergone in pursuing the Value Creation strategy and the benefits we've captured. As we transition to responsible growth, my focus is on ensuring we capture additional operating efficiencies while continuing our disciplined investment process. This means delivering more volume in a profitable, responsible and risk-adjusted way and avoiding the trap of chasing growth for growth's sake.
During my field visits, I have and will continue to drive home the point that we are running a business designed to deliver through-cycle returns, and this demands efficiently growing pretax income while intelligently investing in the business.
Now looking at our homebuilding operations, we had 7,909 homes under construction at the end of the quarter, of which 27% were spec. Consistent with our previous guidance, we purposely increased spec production heading into the spring selling season to help manage and smooth our overall production cadence. With spec sales tracking to plan and finished specs continuing to average well below 1 per community, we are right where we wanted to be during this busy time of the spring selling season. After several months of strong spec starts, and now having a large and growing backlog of sold homes, we have already started reducing the number of specs we've put into production.
Looking at demand conditions for the quarter, we are very pleased with activity in the marketplace these past few months. As you might expect, with a 10% increase in signups for the period, we generally saw positive traffic and demand conditions across the country during the quarter, and I would add that this trend has continued into the first few weeks of April.
In summary, the feedback I've received from our operators during my recent market visits is consistent with what we see in the data. The selling season has gotten off to a very good start. 
Taking us down to a regional level, on the East Coast, overall demand was solid in the quarter and got better as you move from North to South. Consistent with the trend over the last several quarters, we continue to see stronger demand in the Carolinas, Georgia and Florida. We are excited about the long-term opportunities we see in the South, particularly in the Southeast given the migration trends, buyer preferences and land availability. It is one of the reasons why we were interested in the Wieland assets.
Looking at the middle third of the country, we saw broad-based improvement in demand through the Midwest with signups  climbing over 30% for the quarter. Winter weather conditions were a little easier at the start of this year compared with 2015, but we are optimistic that the higher signups for the quarter reflect a more fundamental improvement in demand. 
Dropping down into Texas on a year-over-year basis, signups were essentially flat as exceptional strength in Dallas was offset by softer demand in Houston and San Antonio. Houston demand improved as we moved through the quarter, and the market has performed better than I think many were expecting.
And finally, looking out to our Western markets, we continue to experience good demand, particularly in some of our bigger markets including Northern California, Phoenix and Las Vegas. We had some new communities open in Las Vegas, and it was great to see the market responding favorably to these new locations.
Given the differences in market dynamics that can exist at the local level, it can be tough to generalize, but we would say that demand continues to improve and the communities located closer to city center fare better in terms of sales, prices and paces. The inventory of homes available for sale remains tight in most of our markets and, at least on the new home side, will likely remain that way for a while given the limited supply of finished lots available. 
I have already met some of you at conferences earlier this year, and I look forward to meeting more of you as the year progresses. 
Let me turn the call back to Richard. Richard?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ryan. In summary, we had an excellent quarter and, given our strong backlog and growing production pipeline, are well positioned to have an excellent year. The work we have done since Value Creation began in 2011 has responsibly positioned PulteGr
componenttext:
Thanks, Ryan. In summary, we had an excellent quarter and, given our strong backlog and growing production pipeline, are well positioned to have an excellent year. The work we have done since Value Creation began in 2011 has responsibly positioned PulteGroup to be a through-cycle performer, which is why we look forward to the future with optimism.
I want to close by thanking our terrific PulteGroup employees, who, despite the public distractions these past few weeks, have and continue to do a fantastic job staying focused and delivering for our customers. You are the best team in the business, and I could not be more proud to work side-by-side with you.
Let me turn the call back to Jim Zeumer. Jim?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Richard. We'll open the call for questions. And so that we can speak with as many participants as possible during the remaining time in this call, we ask that you limit yourselves to 1 question and 1 follow-up. Carol, if you'll explain the
componenttext: Great. Thanks, Richard. We'll open the call for questions. And so that we can speak with as many participants as possible during the remaining time in this call, we ask that you limit yourselves to 1 question and 1 follow-up. Carol, if you'll explain the process, we'll get started.

componenttext: Yes, we've talked about that as something we're striving to do. We still have a challenging entitlement process. And so as we go through the year, it's our expectation we'll continue to see improvement relative to last year but that we won't get back to historical averages, at least not during 2016.

componenttext: Susan, it's Richard. The Wieland acquisition is progressing well. The teams are moving through the integration process as expected. We had, what, about 2.5 months in the quarter of total activity from the brand, but it's going well. We have an excellent team focused on integration, and we're pleased with the way it's going so far. So it's early yet, but so far, so good.
