headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Scott, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Q2 2016 PulteGroup, Inc. Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. Jim Zeumer, you may begin your conf
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Scott, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Q2 2016 PulteGroup, Inc. Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. 
Jim Zeumer, you may begin your conference.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Scott, and good morning to everyone participating on today's call. I want to welcome you to PulteGroup's Conference Call to discuss our second quarter financial results for the 3 months ended June 30, 2016. Joining me for today's call
componenttext:
Great. Thank you, Scott, and good morning to everyone participating on today's call. I want to welcome you to PulteGroup's Conference Call to discuss our second quarter financial results for the 3 months ended June 30, 2016. 
Joining me for today's call are Richard Dugas, Chairman and CEO; Ryan Marshall, President; Bob O'shaughnessy, Executive Vice President and CFO; and Jim Ossowski, Vice President Finance and Controller.
A copy of this morning's earnings release and the presentation slides that accompanies -- accompany today's discussion are posted to our corporate website at pultegroupinc.com. We will also post an audio replay of today's call to our website a little later. 
Before we begin, the discussion, I want to alert all participants that today's call -- today's presentation may include forward-looking statement about PulteGroup's future performance. Actual results could differ materially from those suggested by our comments made today. The most significant risk factors that could affect future results are summarized as part of today's earnings release and within the accompanying presentation slides. These risk factors and other key information are detailed in our SEC filings, including our annual and quarterly reports. 
Now let me turn over the call to Richard Dugas. Richard?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you Jim, and good morning, everyone. Over the 5-plus years, we've been operating on our Value Creation strategy, the company has moved to several different stages as our operating financial results progress. When we started back in 2011, our initial
componenttext:
Thank you Jim, and good morning, everyone. Over the 5-plus years, we've been operating on our Value Creation strategy, the company has moved to several different stages as our operating financial results progress. When we started back in 2011, our initial focus is on fixing our fundamental business performance, along with strengthening our balance sheet and enhancing overall returns on in the invested capital. Having made significant progress towards achieving these initial operating and financial objectives, in 2013, we are in a position to begin materially increasing investment in the business.
Our land acquisition spend on an annual basis, the last few years doubled from $600 million or 11% of revenue in 2013 to $1.2 billion or 21% of revenue in 2015. While the dollars grew, our underlying discipline has not wavered. We have continued to invest in higher returning, shorter duration projects that are closer to city centers, allowing the company to maintain higher margins and returns through this timeframe.
As we have talked about on recent calls, 2016 is the year this increased investment begins to pay off, as we have now reached an inflection point toward higher growth in the business.
The earnings release we issued this morning demonstrates this point as our second quarter results show another quarter of strong year-over-year growth across a variety of important business metrics, including sign-ups, which increased 11% in units and 21% in value; closings which increased by 21%; revenues which increased 41% to $1.8 billion; earnings per share, which gained 21% on a reported basis and was significantly higher when you adjust for the charges and benefits in their respective reporting periods; and with our backlog value of 21% to $3.7 billion, our highest since 2007, we are in an excellent position to realize further growth over the remainder of 2016.
It is clear that after 3 years of increased investment in the business, we are driving meaningful growth across the operations. While our increased land investments should bring growth for several years to come, we have not forgotten that home building is a cyclical business, which is why we are already planning for the future.
Value Creation was designed over 5 years ago to help maximize shareholder value through an entire housing cycle. With this in mind, in addition to announcing our strong second quarter financial results, this morning's earnings release highlighted additional actions we are now taking as we move through the housing cycle.
After 4 years during which our investment in new land grew significantly, we plan to slow the rate of growth in our new investment in 2017 and beyond. With 143,000 lots currently under control, we maintain a very strong land pipeline in which to operate over the next few years.
Our stated capital allocation priorities of first investing in high returning land and then returning excess funds to shareholders have not changed. As such, given a moderated level of land spend in future years, we expect to have sufficient liquidity to allow us to increase our share repurchase activities. 
As stated in the release, our board has approved an incremental $1 billion share repurchase authorization, bringing our total authorization to $1.5 billion.
As also stated, we expect to utilize that authority over the next 18 months through repurchases of $250 million in each of the third and fourth quarters of 2016 and an additional $1 billion in 2017.
Along with looking to create value through our allocation of capital over time, we are also taking action to create value through maximizing efficiencies within our operations. Over the past several years, we have worked extremely hard to raise our operating margin from the bottom quartile of the homebuilding peers to among the industry leaders.
We want to maintain and as possible, enhance, our relative position. To help realize this objective, we plan to lower our SG&A spend from an estimated 10% of revenues in 2016 to 9% of revenues or lower in 2017.
While we expect to realize a portion of this leverage benefit from increased revenues, we are also working to take unnecessary overhead out of the business. The fact is that after 5 years, many of our core homebuilding disciplines put in place at the outset of Value Creation are now part of the company standard operating practices and are embedded in our muscle memory.
As such, there are opportunities to remove some of these costs.
As I wrap up my initial comments, let me say that I'm very proud of the excellent second quarter results and pleased with how well we are positioned for the future. Furthermore, I believe the additional actions we are not announcing today with regard to future capital allocation and overheads will help ensure we continue building value for shareholders going forward. 
Now let me turn over the call to Bob for a detailed review of the quarter. Bob?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Richard, and good morning. Building on our strong Q1 results, PulteGroup second quarter financials are highlighted by significant growth and performance gains in the business.Looking at the second quarter's homebuilding operations, home sale rev
componenttext:
Thanks, Richard, and good morning. Building on our strong Q1 results, PulteGroup second quarter financials are highlighted by significant growth and performance gains in the business.
Looking at the second quarter's homebuilding operations, home sale revenues were at $1.8 billion, which represents an increase of 41% over last year. The significant increase in revenues is driven by a 27% increase in closings, the 4,772 homes, combined with an 11% or $35,000 increase in average selling price to $367,000.
The 27% increase in closings was due to the strong orders we have reported in recent quarters, coupled with our previously discussed actions to put additional homes into production at the end of last year and the beginning of this year. As a result, our conversion rate for the quarter was 55%, which is up roughly 600 basis points over last year.
I'd like to point out that although our conversion rate improved on a year-over-year basis in the second quarter, tight labor resources, elongated build cycles and development and permitting delays remain meaningful challenges across many markets. As such, we continue to target conversion rate improvement versus last year, but don't expect we will return to the rates several years ago in the short-term.
As a result, we currently project the conversion rate of between 51% and 54% in the third quarter this year.  This compares to the 48% conversion rate in Q3 of last year.
The 11% increase in average selling price for the quarter reflect the ongoing shift in the midst of our business product towards our move up product.
In addition to the shift in our mix, we also realized higher prices in each buyer group, including a 5% increase among first-time buyers to $270,000 and 11% increase of the price up move-up homes to $438,000 and a 4% increase in the average price of homes among our active adult buyers, $357,000.
During the quarter, closing percentage by buyer group were as follows: 29% first-time; 44% move-up; and 27% active adult. In Q2 of last year, closings by buyer group were 34% first-time; 35%, move-up; and 31% active adult.
Given that our backlog ASP of $387,000 is up 13% over last year, and up 5% from Q2 deliveries, we expect ASPs will continually to move gradually higher over the coming quarters.
Our second quarter gross margin of 21.5%, which includes approximately 70 basis points of drag associated with our first quarter acquisition of the Wieland assets, was in line with previous guidance.
Adjusting for the impact of the Wieland closings, gross margins were down approximately 110 basis points from last year, primarily as a result of mix, buyer land and labor costs.
The company remains on track to deliver full year margins of approximately 21.5%, and we expect margins over the remaining 2 quarters to be in the range of 21.2% to 21.7%, which is down slightly from prior guidance of 21.5% to 22%.
Based on our current backlog, we see higher labor and material cost continuing to put slight pressure on margins.
Offsetting some of the margin pressure, we continue to have success with our strategic pricing programs. In Q2, our total option revenues and lot premiums increased 5% over last year to approximately $67,000 per closing.
In addition, sales discounts totaled 2.7%, which is up about 50 basis points from last year, but consistent with our first quarter of this year's results.
Second quarter SG&A was $192 million or 11% of home sale revenues. Prior year SG&A spend of $130 million or 10.5% of revenues, included a $27 million benefit, where approximately 210 basis points resulting from a legal settlement.
Increased SG&A spend in the quarter reflects ongoing growth in support of the company's 26% increase in units underproduction, combined with cost associated with higher health care insurance and professional fees incurred in the period.
Although the asset dollar spend is higher than forecasted, we still expect full year SG&A will be approximately 10% of revenues, allowing PulteGroup to maintaining its operating margin among the industry leaders.
At 10% of revenue, SG&A expenses are certainly within historical ranges, but as Richard discussed, we believe there are opportunities to drive greater overhead leverage. Based on our current targets, we expect to drive SG&A spend lower by at least 100 [ph] basis points in 2017 to 9% or lower of home sale revenues.
Continuing down the income statement, we reported other expenses net of $13 million. This includes approximately $7 million of deposits and other pre-acquisition charges associated with the termination of several pending land transactions as well as the final $7 million of costs associated with the relocation of our corporate office.
Turning to financial services, we reported pretax income of $17 million, which is up from $10 million last year. These results benefited from the higher closing volumes in our homebuilding operations as well as the favorable interest rate environment given the declining rates experienced during the quarter.
Our mortgage capture rate for the period was 81%, down from 83% in the second quarter of 2015.
Consistent with guidance, our effective tax rate for the quarter was 38%, building [ph] Q2 net income of $118 million or $0.34 per share. EPS for the quarter was calculated on approximately 348 million shares, which is down 4% from last year, resulting largely from share repurchase activities.
Moving to income statement homebuilding operations, we had 8,687 homes under construction at the end of the second quarter, of which 23% were SPEC [ph] . Consistent with our Q1 comments, after increasing the SPEC home production at the back half of '15 and into the first quarter of 2016, that helped ensure more consistent construction work cadence, we have slowed somewhat as we build the backlog from the selling season.
With an average of less than 1 finished spec [ph] per community, we remain in a very favorable inventory position.
In the second quarter, we approved approximately 5,800 lots for purchase shares and ended the period with 143,000 lots under control.
Consistent with recent quarters, about total that position is controlled through options as we work to manage our land risk and drive higher returns on invested capital.  On our controlled lots, approximately 25% are developed. 
During the quarter, we spent $370 million -- $379 [ph] million on land acquisition and generally remain on track with 2016 plans to invest approximately $1.6  billion, including the purchase of the Wieland assets in new land positions. Consistent with Richards comments and after several years of significant growth, we expect the rate of our growth of our land acquisition spend to slow as we head into 2017.
Recognizing that the current housing cycle is maturing, we are decreasing our land investment as a percentage of revenues and could ultimately reduce to asset dollars was spent debating assessment of economic condition and their potential impact on the housing industry here in the U.S.
Looking at share repurchase activities during the quarter, we repurchased 2.6 million shares for $48 million or $18.51 per share.  This brings our total repurchase activity for the first half of the year to $98 million.
Expanding on Richard's earlier comments about capital allocation, we've invested significantly in land-related development over the last few years, and we expect those investments of dry volume growth and strong cash flows for the next few years.
We've also indicated that the growth in our investment is expected to moderate going forward. As a result, we feel we are well-positioned to increase the return of funds per shareholders, consistent with our stated capital allocation priorities expenditure buyback program which are outlined.
We expect to take on a certain amount of incremental debt and connection with the outlined share repurchase activity, but we expect to be able to maintaining a responsible and certainly very manageable debt to cap level throughout this process. As a reminder, our target debt to cap range remains unchanged at 30% to 40%. While we may have leverage rates outside this range at points in time but we continue to believe our targeted range is appropriate and we'll strive to operate in that range over the long-term.
I'll just provide a couple more data points before turning over the call. 
Sign ups [ph] for the second quarter were 5,697, which represents an increase of 11% over the prior year. On a dollar basis, sign ups increased to even greater 21%, $2.1 billion.
Sign ups by buyer group breakdown as follows: first time increased 12%; move-up increased 21%; and active adult declined 3%. Adjusted for changes in community counts, absorption phases increased to 23% and 5% for first-time and active adult buyers, respectively, but were lower by 8% among move-up buyers. As we've talked about on our prior call, given the higher price points among Wieland Communities, absorption paces are slower than traditional communities, which impacted the move up buyer results.
During the second quarter, we operated for 700 communities, which is up 11% over last year. The 11% increase is in line with prior company guidance for year-over-year growth in community count of 8% to 10% in the first half of the year, expanding to 10% to 15% in the second half of 2016.
Now let me turn the call over to Ryan Marshall for some comments on marketing conditions. Ryan?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. While there's been a lot of volatility in the global economic and financial markets, U.S. housing continues to move along the slow recovery path it has been following for the past 5 years.Government data as of May, showing new home sales of
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. While there's been a lot of volatility in the global economic and financial markets, U.S. housing continues to move along the slow recovery path it has been following for the past 5 years.
Government data as of May, showing new home sales of 550,000, puts U.S. housing on track to deliver another year of roughly 10% growth. The trend is certainly positive, but after 5 years of recovery, we still remain well below the 50-year average, which is why we believe the recovery has a few years left. And while there's a lot of noise in the surrounding environment, there are certainly positives to be seen in the underlying economy job market, consumer confidence and the low mortgage rate conditions that are important drivers of ongoing demand.
The demand conditions we realized in Q2 are consistent with those suggested by some of the broader housing stats which point to a sustained recovery, but with pockets of stronger and weaker demand depending on geography and buyer segment. 
On a regional basis, demand conditions in the quarter were as follows: consistent with comments made on many of our prior calls, demand on the East Coast generally gets stronger as you move from north to south. Florida, Georgia and parts of the Carolinas continue to experience solid buyer demand as we benefited from strong local economies.
Getting to home sold in some of our mid-Atlantic and Northeast markets is a little more challenging as demand appears to be softer than start of the year.
The middle third of the country covering our Midwest and Texas operations continue to experience strong demand conditions. All of our Midwest markets have been performing well, would notable gains in our of Ohio and Kentucky operations as we continue to build on the dominion positions we acquired in 2014.
Our Texas markets are generally performing well. Dallas continues to experience exceptional strength, although maintaining that needed pace of land development in the market is challenging. Houston is still showing great resilience as demand continues to exceed expectations. Excessive rains earlier in the year has meant development for Houston and Austin, but our teams are working hard to catch up on some of the delays.
And finally, looking out west, demand remains solid throughout the area with good traffic and sign up paces in Arizona, Nevada and California.
Although it is among our smaller markets, Seattle has realized a nice jump in buyer demand as we  get new communities open and new product on the ground.
Overall, we are certainly pleased with the selling season for PulteGroup, as we realized good absorption paces and built a sizable backlog of sold homes. Our Q2 backlog is the highest in almost a decade, which sets us up well for the remainder of 2016. Having a large backlog allows us to provide a consistent flow of production, which just helpful with it comes to working with the trade base, so that we expect we'll be stretched for the foreseeable future.
In closing, I want to recognize the entire PulteGroup organization, with special thanks to the sales and construction teams which are doing an outstanding job capitalizing on the market opportunities and managing the challenges that develop. Thanks to your effort, we had tremendous momentum heading into the second half of the year. 
Let me now turn the call back to Richard for a few final comments. Richard?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ryan. Before we open the call to questions, I want to take just a couple of minutes to comment on the other press release we issued this morning regarding the addition of 3 very talented executives to serve as independent directors on PulteGroup's
componenttext:
Thanks, Ryan. Before we open the call to questions, I want to take just a couple of minutes to comment on the other press release we issued this morning regarding the addition of 3 very talented executives to serve as independent directors on PulteGroup's board. 
For those of you who have followed home building over the years, you will likely know the name John Peskin. John spent much of his 30-year home building career with Taylor Woodrow, including serving as the company CEO for 6 years. John has also served on the boards of Standard Pacific and WCI Communities. 
I'm also pleased to welcome Josh Gotbaum to the PulteGroup board. After spending more than a decade in investment banking at Lazard [ph], Josh held senior-level positions in the U.S. government and has recently served as acting Chief Operating Officer of the Pension Benefit Guarantee [ph] Corporation.  Josh's extensive Wall Street and government experience will be a great add to the collective experience of our board. 
Also joining our board will be Scott Powers, a financial services executive with over 30 years of experience. Scott, who is most recently President and CEO of State Street Global Advisors, has a long track record of success with some of the industry's premier asset managers including Home Mutual, Mellon [ph] Financial and Boston Company. 
We look forward to having the experiences of 3 such proven executives added to our board. I would also note that in addition to joining the board, John and Josh have both been added to the search committee, which was recently established to identify PulteGroup's next CEO. The committee's work is well underway as they evaluate internal and external candidates. John and Josh will go to work immediately to get actively engaged in the process.
And finally, I want to confirm that over the past several weeks, we have had conversations about broad business strategies and practices with Elliott Management, one of the company's shareholders. We certainly appreciate their perspectives about PulteGroup and ideas for creating long-term value for shareholders. 
I would also tell you that from our very first conversation, we were in agreement with many of their thoughts because we had already been evaluating the same opportunities to enhance the business and potential returns for our shareholders. 
As an example, PulteGroup's efforts to supplement its board with direct homebuilding and additional Wall Street experience were already underway. The final candidate selection was the result of a fruitful collaboration and discussion with Elliott. In short, all our discussions with Elliott were constructive and productive.
Beyond just speaking with Elliott, we had extensive conversations with many other large shareholders over the past several weeks and months. The feedback has been very consistent in terms of investor support for our Value Creation Strategy and the tactics we have been implementing. We view the planned actions we announced today on capital allocation, land spend, SG&A and corporate governance as appropriate next steps in our value creation work as we work hard to drive greater shareholder value from here. 
Now let me turn call back to Jim Zeumer. Jim?

componenttext: Jack, we definitely discussed before, we would like to get the land -- total land number lower for sure. We have been over the last 5 years buying much shorter positions. componenttext: Guidance on backlog conversions with the extra guidance there. So thank you for that. First question just on the expected cash flow from operations. Is there any land sales contemplated over the next several quarters that's going to be a source of cash?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Allen, we have sold about $400 million worth of land over the last several years, and we're continually looking to prune unproductive assets. So that will continue, probably not in any great rate, not a big slug in any one time, but slowly over time you'l
componenttext: Allen, we have sold about $400 million worth of land over the last several years, and we're continually looking to prune unproductive assets. So that will continue, probably not in any great rate, not a big slug in any one time, but slowly over time you'll see that number continue to flow through a little bit. But to be clear, with all the investment we put in over the past 4 years, which as you know, has been in the 30% to 40% annual range in terms of increases year-over-year, we'll have substantial cash coming off the business just from that investment for at least the next few years. So as we begin to moderate the rate of growth, we are still going to have a substantial growth over the next few years, but the rate of cash coming in recently, the incremental cash going out for land, will free up quite a bit of capital for repurchases. So to be clear, we are not intending on you check land sales to fund the buyback.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And second question, just -- you made a comment that even with the slowing growth of land spend, you still think there are several years of growth in the business. So I was hoping you might be able to frame that for us, within the context of y
componenttext: Understood. And second question, just -- you made a comment that even with the slowing growth of land spend, you still think there are several years of growth in the business. So I was hoping you might be able to frame that for us, within the context of your comments about the cycle and where we are? It sounds like you used a different language this quarter just as far as maybe coming a little bit closer to the end of the cycle or at least shifting the strategy a little bit. So I think, there's this view that the markets and the pretty steady growth pace, call it 10% plus or minus, and there's several large builders that expect that type of growth to continue for the next several years. So a, would you agree with that as far as the market is concerned? And b, within that specific, how do you see you trending versus the market as you move out beyond 2017?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Alan, Richard here. Again, couple of things. We do agree with that statement, the slow and steady path for the next several years overall. The fact is, we've been stepping on the gas pretty hard the last few years with regard to land spend. We're jus
componenttext: Yes, Alan, Richard here. Again, couple of things. We do agree with that statement, the slow and steady path for the next several years overall. The fact is, we've been stepping on the gas pretty hard the last few years with regard to land spend. We're just going to made right that a bit which will free up quite a bit of cash from operations, but that's our view collectively on the market. The second piece is realized that we have a large land-based that we need to monetize. And we're going to work really hard to have that continue to drive business for us.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: What a -- lot of stuff to digest today. Just wanted to start, Richard, when you're thinking about 2017 and maybe to Alan's question, is the right way to think about how you're planning for the business at 2017 is going to be the peak year for deliveries,
componenttext: What a -- lot of stuff to digest today. Just wanted to start, Richard, when you're thinking about 2017 and maybe to Alan's question, is the right way to think about how you're planning for the business at 2017 is going to be the peak year for deliveries, relative to the fact that land spend is going to down, so delivery should peak out in 2017 but you have a lower capital base in a more efficient balance sheet? Is that the strategy? Or am I missing something here?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, I wouldn't necessarily say that 2017 will be the peak year for deliveries. The reality is that land that we put in place today, it's 24 plus months before it comes online. So when we began increasing investment back in '13, we knew that '16 would be
componenttext: Bob, I wouldn't necessarily say that 2017 will be the peak year for deliveries. The reality is that land that we put in place today, it's 24 plus months before it comes online. So when we began increasing investment back in '13, we knew that '16 would be a big year, and we're expecting growth from here. So I can't comment on exactly when that growth peaks, and I'll point out that we are talking about only moderating the growth rate of land, not necessarily cutting the rate of land. So we're still projecting solid growth for the next several years, and I want to be clear about that. So I wouldn't call for 2017 to be the peak. The reality is, we should be getting more and more efficient as we monetize this large land-based we already have.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's an important distinction and a helpful one. Thanks for clarifying that. Can you walk me through and maybe the ball goes to Bob's court, you're slowing the pace of land, it's partially calling the cycle, it's partially an effort to get better financ
componenttext: That's an important distinction and a helpful one. Thanks for clarifying that. Can you walk me through and maybe the ball goes to Bob's court, you're slowing the pace of land, it's partially calling the cycle, it's partially an effort to get better financial performance through the balance sheet, but what's the logic behind levering up to buy back stock, given the fact that the stock is now trading at close to 2x book, and obviously, that's a positive thing, which shows the Value Creation plan has worked. So from my standpoint, I'm trying to understand if the cycle is further along than we have anticipated, does it make sense to run to 40% to 50%? Why do you want to reinvest back on a systematic buyback program, given the fact that the underlying land in your existing balance sheets already appreciated in the market recognizes the good work?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, it's worth remembering, if you go back to, call it December of '14, when we had our Investor Day and laid out what our uses of capital were going to be, this is really the execution of that. So we highlighted -- we want to invest in high-growth or hi
componenttext: Bob, it's worth remembering, if you go back to, call it December of '14, when we had our Investor Day and laid out what our uses of capital were going to be, this is really the execution of that. So we highlighted -- we want to invest in high-growth or higher return opportunities here and when that -- as we've talked about, has moderated, not stopping to Richard's point, but moderating the growth of it. So we'll still be investing a fair amount of money, using that excess cash flow to return to shareholders and the important thing -- you've asked the question is around that it hinges on just the cap between 30% and 40%. Today we're at 35%. We're talking about incremental leverage over that next 18 months, but isn't really terribly significant. Again, we've -- we highlighted that we might go a little bit above 40%, but not a lot. And again, what we've indicated is that we would see to get back down under 40% as time goes by, because that's what we've outlined in terms of our priorities. So we've not tried to make a determination of markets, so when we've been buying back equity over the last 2 or 3 years, we have been -- we have a view about market values, but typically, we are buying on the relatively consistent basis, with the cash we have available, and other than trading what we think is intelligent as the market price changes, we are not saying we think the stock is expensive returning shareholder bonds.

componenttext: Also, a lot to digest and I think, a lot of good stuff. Just wanted to try and get a little bit more clarity as we think about 2017. Secondly, you've reiterated your community count guidance for the back half of the year, how should we think about community count in 2017? It seems that you should still be able to do some amount of closings growth, but maybe sub 10%. Is that fair?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Richard. I want to be crystal clear for everyone on the call. What we're doing today will not impact our 2017 volumes. What we buy lead in this space, it's for at least 24 months out. No one should model or change their view on what our growth sho
componenttext: This is Richard. I want to be crystal clear for everyone on the call. What we're doing today will not impact our 2017 volumes. What we buy lead in this space, it's for at least 24 months out. No one should model or change their view on what our growth should be relative to 2017 here, at all. That's why we commented extensively in our release that we will be growing for the next several years. And I also want to point out, we're talking about moderate the rate of growth in our land spend, and we've been growing substantially. So there's lots of growth to come. The relied thus and we have a large balance sheet and we're just going to monetize that to a better degree, I believe, than we have in the past and use the cash flow to help buyback equity. And to a comment that was asked on the previous question, no one's talking about leverage anywhere near 50% here. Bob stated very clearly, we want to stay within that 30% to 40% range and if we get outside of it, we'll work hard to bring it back in. So I just want to clarify there.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that. And I guess, again, how it affects your 2017 not withstanding, what you're saying it won't, I think, if there's any ability to give any sense of how you're thinking about closing volume growth for next year, that would be helpful. And a
componenttext: I appreciate that. And I guess, again, how it affects your 2017 not withstanding, what you're saying it won't, I think, if there's any ability to give any sense of how you're thinking about closing volume growth for next year, that would be helpful. And also, kind of moving onto the second question, again, the incremental clarity, when I -- I just ran some very quick numbers on some more share buyback and a little more leverage or a little more debt, and it does appear that at worst, being a -- perhaps a 40% to 45% range, and again, that would be for a brief amount of time. Is that the right way to think about that, Bob?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Let me just address those. Typically, to your first question on '17, we would give color on '17 later this year, and we would expect to do that not today. In terms of the leverage rates. Again like anything else in the life, depends on when we go to
componenttext: Yes. Let me just address those. Typically, to your first question on '17, we would give color on '17 later this year, and we would expect to do that not today. In terms of the leverage rates. Again like anything else in the life, depends on when we go to market, how the business cash flows our generated over time. But again, I would tell you that our expectation is at the end of '17, with the buyback levels that we are talking about, we don't think we get much outside of 40%.

So I have more to say on our Q3 call, clearly about the detail there, but we expect to reduce our overhead costs in Q3.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll answer the first, and then maybe Bob or Ryan could comment on the business, excluding Wieland. I'm not involved in the search, Stephen, but I do know the committee is underway. They've engaged an outside firm and they intend to get to 2 new directors
componenttext: I'll answer the first, and then maybe Bob or Ryan could comment on the business, excluding Wieland. I'm not involved in the search, Stephen, but I do know the committee is underway. They've engaged an outside firm and they intend to get to 2 new directors up to speed immediately. And I know there's plans to do that, like literally, immediately. So I can't speak for the committee, but I would hope that over the next couple of months, they would be able to wrap up their work. So not specificity there, but sometime in the not-too-distant future, I would think. And then on the other.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Steven, on Wieland, we're not going to give detail on Wieland versus the rest of the business. Offer is their absorption pace, as we highlighted, were up 23%; and first-time, down 8% [ph] ; and move up, up 5%, nack [ph] of the bill [ph]. Again, Wieland si
componenttext: Steven, on Wieland, we're not going to give detail on Wieland versus the rest of the business. Offer is their absorption pace, as we highlighted, were up 23%; and first-time, down 8% [ph] ; and move up, up 5%, nack [ph] of the bill [ph]. Again, Wieland sits in that move up space and absent the Wieland business that would have been flat year-over-year. So in total, our absorption pace is flat Q2 versus Q2 last year. It would've been up somewhat instead, if we hadn't had the Wieland business. And we did highlight 70 basis points of margin.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Eric Bosshard from Cleveland Research.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Curious as you look at the business now from a segment standpoint where the demand is or for land costs or where land close are or where selling prices are, and what you're seeing in the business that has you evaluating where we are in the cycle is what I
componenttext: Curious as you look at the business now from a segment standpoint where the demand is or for land costs or where land close are or where selling prices are, and what you're seeing in the business that has you evaluating where we are in the cycle is what I'm trying to figure out.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Eric, it's fair to say that we feel like we're somewhere in the middle of the cycle, we're not in the early stages of the cycle. It is maturing and land costs are up. I'll echo something that Bob put in his script, we're proud of our operating margin
componenttext: Yes, Eric, it's fair to say that we feel like we're somewhere in the middle of the cycle, we're not in the early stages of the cycle. It is maturing and land costs are up. I'll echo something that Bob put in his script, we're proud of our operating margin performance. We are taking some SG&A action to help keep that as land prices and labor prices are not allowing quite as much pricing power as we've had in the past I want to count the gross margin side. So it's a very healthy housing market. We're really pleased with our absorption paces and we project in next few years we're going to bring more of the same.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just to follow up, that's helpful. I can understand the land and labor influence on the cost side of the gross margin equation. I guess on the selling price side of that, where within the markets -- are there segments of the market where  -- or segments o
componenttext: Just to follow up, that's helpful. I can understand the land and labor influence on the cost side of the gross margin equation. I guess on the selling price side of that, where within the markets -- are there segments of the market where  -- or segments of demand where it's harder to raise price to earn a really attractive gross margin that makes you feel a little bit different about volume?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Eric, this is Ryan. What I would tell you is that the first few weeks of July have continued to show typical seasonal selling patterns. And we continue to see local economies drive pockets of strength and/or weaknesses we move across the country. One grea
componenttext: Eric, this is Ryan. What I would tell you is that the first few weeks of July have continued to show typical seasonal selling patterns. And we continue to see local economies drive pockets of strength and/or weaknesses we move across the country. One great example that I'll give you is our Dallas market. That's a market where the local economy continues to do very well, and we're seeing nice pricing power throughout all of the segments.  And the other thing that I would just point out to you, Eric, is we continue to say to our Value Creation strategy that our focus is on driving high returns. Margins are certainly a component of driving high returns, but it's not the only thing that we focus on.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: I guess in terms of -- you get some regional color on Florida in the Northeast, which I found interesting, because markets like the mid-Atlantic for resale were quite strong. Can you talk about where you saw the pockets of softness on Northeast as well as the pockets of strength in Florida?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Will, where we've seen pockets of relative weakness over prior year, we are in the Northeast market specifically, New Jersey and our Boston area of markets. We saw a nice strength in D.C. and throughout Florida, was very strong.
componenttext: Yes, Will, where we've seen pockets of relative weakness over prior year, we are in the Northeast market specifically, New Jersey and our Boston area of markets. We saw a nice strength in D.C. and throughout Florida, was very strong.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then, I hate to beat a dead horse, but in terms of reduced land spend, should we anticipate that that's mainly targeted, I'll call, none faulty homes brand specifically, probably more like Centex? And I guess, as a side note in terms of cash flows, Du
componenttext: And then, I hate to beat a dead horse, but in terms of reduced land spend, should we anticipate that that's mainly targeted, I'll call, none faulty homes brand specifically, probably more like Centex? And I guess, as a side note in terms of cash flows, Dusty's mean that you're not necessarily pursuing an investment grade rating over the next, I'll call it, 1.5 years?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Will, this is Richard. We're not giving color on where exactly our moderation land spend will affect us. As Bob indicated as we get closer to the end of the year, we'll provide additional color going forward. But I want to be clear, that won't be affectin
componenttext: Will, this is Richard. We're not giving color on where exactly our moderation land spend will affect us. As Bob indicated as we get closer to the end of the year, we'll provide additional color going forward. But I want to be clear, that won't be affecting the next couple of years for the volume. And then, with regard to investment grade, I'll just make one opening comment and then I'll turn it to Bob. We are intending to maintain our investment discipline and our debt to capital discipline, which we've outlined 5 years ago as part of Value Creation, was our target range. So with that, Bob, you want to talk about the range?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just make two comments. One, on the capital to your question. I don't think it would change our perspective. Our land teams have had -- we are agnostic to what land they're buying. So we're not going to say -- we're not going to spend as much, and in
componenttext: I'll just make two comments. One, on the capital to your question. I don't think it would change our perspective. Our land teams have had -- we are agnostic to what land they're buying. So we're not going to say -- we're not going to spend as much, and in particular we don't you to buy entry-level or something like that. So the teams have the capacity to make the investment decisions. And then with respect to the agencies, I think, Richard said it all. We will maintaining the discipline we have. We think we've got a business that is supported of an investment great whether they get there or not. This will introduce some more leverage, but certainly, within the guidance that we outlined. And if not, what we could seek to get back inside.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Zener from KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Zener from KeyBanc.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In regards to the gross margin for the back half, I wonder if you could explore that a little bit. I mean, I see the order paces going along with how we would expect I wonder you had this really strong growth in closings, specially in the first half in ge
componenttext: In regards to the gross margin for the back half, I wonder if you could explore that a little bit. I mean, I see the order paces going along with how we would expect I wonder you had this really strong growth in closings, specially in the first half in general. What was the factor or region that is causing that modest trim down? Realizing you're obviously taking costs actions on the G&A side to offset that structurally, but could you go into that a little bit? Is it labor? Is it the land? Is it the pricing wasn't as strong? And within regions.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, the answer is all of the above to some extent. Certainly Wieland is impacting our margins, consistent with the way we thought they would. Mix matters. If you look at our second quarter of this year versus second quarter of last year, Del Webb [ph
componenttext: I think, the answer is all of the above to some extent. Certainly Wieland is impacting our margins, consistent with the way we thought they would. Mix matters. If you look at our second quarter of this year versus second quarter of last year, Del Webb [ph] or active adult, I should say, is less of a contributor and it is our highest margin business. So that, on a mix adjusted basis, takes our margins down. And to be clear, and we've said this over time, land prices have gone up over time and add more expensive land cycles to our mix. Labor costs are up. We have a generally positive or favorable commodity market, so the input cost there but labor's expensive. We suggested and we've guided that 1.5% to 2% growth in our house costs and again a lot of that is labor. So all those things factor in as we look at what we've had occur in this quarter and what's going to happen in the next couple of quarters.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Kevin, this is Richard. I'll just add one thing. We are committed to operating margin excellence regardless of what gross margins are doing and we're pleased with where our gross margins are. They are still on a relative basis, quite strong, but we ju
componenttext: And Kevin, this is Richard. I'll just add one thing. We are committed to operating margin excellence regardless of what gross margins are doing and we're pleased with where our gross margins are. They are still on a relative basis, quite strong, but we just want to be clear that we want to maintain our lean and operating margins.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I understand that, and obviously, you're taking the SG&A action. In regards to your comment, since you're not talking about '17 in terms of operational metrics like closings or community count. And your land action this year are not impacting '17. Could y
componenttext: I understand that, and obviously, you're taking the SG&A action. In regards to your comment, since you're not talking about '17 in terms of operational metrics like closings or community count. And your land action this year are not impacting '17. Could you talk about the volume assumptions? Or I mean, how are you getting to that 9%? Is it just on cost reductions, efficiency? Or how much leverage is occurring due to variables you're not commenting on, I guess? How would you ...

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's a bit of both. We're counting on revenue growth and volume growth, and we're counting on dollars, actual dollars coming out of the business as well. We're not providing any more color than that at this stage, as Bob indicated, we'll have more to
componenttext: Yes, it's a bit of both. We're counting on revenue growth and volume growth, and we're counting on dollars, actual dollars coming out of the business as well. We're not providing any more color than that at this stage, as Bob indicated, we'll have more to say a little bit later in the year. But we are pleased with the fact that we'll be getting incremental leverage in the business next year. And the other thing I'll just say about it, is our '17 volumes will be driven by what we invested in '14, '15 timeframe, primarily. So that's why we know we'll have growth.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Not to beat a dead horse here, but the 9% SG&A target, I just want to be clear that you guys think that you can achieve that kind of on leverage on volume and also some structural cost reductions and it's not really coming at the expense of community count growth, is that correct?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's 100% correct, yes.
componenttext: That's 100% correct, yes.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay and then if I missed this, I apologize. In the press release, you talked about a $0.03 charge from pending land transactions and also corporate relocation. Maybe if you can give a little bit more detail on that, particularly on the corporate relocation, which I thought would have been well behind this at this point?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As we highlighted, that's actually what we think of the final cost associated with that and really, we vacated the last space we had in Michigan. So it just was dependent on when we actually got folks consolidated in one spot. So we think that one is
componenttext: Yes. As we highlighted, that's actually what we think of the final cost associated with that and really, we vacated the last space we had in Michigan. So it just was dependent on when we actually got folks consolidated in one spot. So we think that one is completely behind us now. As it relates to the pending land transaction, essentially, it's one fairly significant and complex transaction that we've been working on for a number of years. The entitlements were challenging. And as we move forward, because of some of the cost elements of candidly, the deals have been a lot of sense and rather than push it forward, because we had a lot of money invested in, we decided to a? Rather than long-term problem for us. So kind of a unique circumstance in that regard.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Susan Maklari from UBS.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: In the last call, you guys went through and you gave some really good information around your impairment and how to think about the margin impact as those lot them back. And as -- we're 1 quarter further in and we hear about this newer land strategy or th
componenttext: In the last call, you guys went through and you gave some really good information around your impairment and how to think about the margin impact as those lot them back. And as -- we're 1 quarter further in and we hear about this newer land strategy or this updated land strategy that's coming together. Is there any change in the thought around those impaired assets and perhaps the timing or the pace in which they may come and you start closing more homes on them?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to be clear, we haven't changed our strategy with respect to land. All we've said is we're not going to grow our investment in land as the 30%-plus rate that we have for the last 3 to 4 years. Our strategies remain the same. In terms of our abil
componenttext: Just want to be clear, we haven't changed our strategy with respect to land. All we've said is we're not going to grow our investment in land as the 30%-plus rate that we have for the last 3 to 4 years. Our strategies remain the same. In terms of our ability to monetize those assets, you heard Richard say, we've sold probably 400-ish million dollars on the last 4 or 5 years of noncore assets. And so we will continue to seek to do that. Those will be kind of lumpy, as things become marketable if they are out there, and there are a ton of them candidly. We've got, as an example, less than $100 million on the balance sheet today of land held for sale, which is stuff that we would think would transact in the short -- relatively short term. Obviously, with respect to some of our order longer data positions, we talked about those pretty consistently over time to drive the best return we can off of forward investment. And so as demand is there, we will sell those.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then in terms of taxes, I know you noted in your comments that you are a bit behind on the operations there because of the rain that was experienced earlier in the year. But you had some good closings and you had some order growth there actually. Can
componenttext: And then in terms of taxes, I know you noted in your comments that you are a bit behind on the operations there because of the rain that was experienced earlier in the year. But you had some good closings and you had some order growth there actually. Can you just give us a bit more color on that?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Susan, this is Ryan. We're fairly pleased with what's happening out of our Texas operations, including the demand. Certainly the weather has been a factor. I'll tell you that the weather is probably more greatly impacted our ability to develop land a
componenttext: Yes, Susan, this is Ryan. We're fairly pleased with what's happening out of our Texas operations, including the demand. Certainly the weather has been a factor. I'll tell you that the weather is probably more greatly impacted our ability to develop land as the third has just become so saturated with, we have to wait for it to dry up. We don't anticipate that having a significant effect on our operations and ability to deliver future closing out of our Texas markets.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Susan, the conversion improvement that we have in the quarter, which Bob noted, we expect continued improvement vis-à-vis last year. That's a result of the better pace of inventory management that we put in place over the past 6 to 9 months. I think,
componenttext: And Susan, the conversion improvement that we have in the quarter, which Bob noted, we expect continued improvement vis-à-vis last year. That's a result of the better pace of inventory management that we put in place over the past 6 to 9 months. I think, Ryan detailed that quite a bit on the last call. And we are pleased we've got more inventory in the ground that is helping.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Dahl from Crédit Suisse.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Was hoping to ask one more question about just kind of framing the margin environment. And on the 9% SG&A, how much of getting from 10% to 9% in fiscal '16 to '17 -- how much of that is incremental to your prior  what you have prior plan -- prior to this?
componenttext: Was hoping to ask one more question about just kind of framing the margin environment. And on the 9% SG&A, how much of getting from 10% to 9% in fiscal '16 to '17 -- how much of that is incremental to your prior  what you have prior plan -- prior to this? And should we think of is as -- you talked about some of the gross margin pressures, you're obviously, focused on holding operating margin. So is it kind of fair to characterize that as we look ahead, your current kind of gross margin base is roughly that 50 to 100 basis points lower that you're now looking to offset on the SG&A side?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, we're not giving guidance beyond what we have in terms of margin. I think, what we're trying to communicate on the expense side is we're looking to maintain the efficiency of our operations. We think we have an opportunity to run the business with a
componenttext: Mike, we're not giving guidance beyond what we have in terms of margin. I think, what we're trying to communicate on the expense side is we're looking to maintain the efficiency of our operations. We think we have an opportunity to run the business with a little bit less costs. And so I don't think there's any correlation necessarily between the margin conversation and expense conversation. The margins will be what they are depending on market conditions and our ability to control costs. We are going to try and drive better efficiency in our operations to reduce expenses.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then secondly, just since there is this, the new buyback out there, and the bulk of it is coming at a point when leadership transition. And so if we think about kind of the search that's going on and the candidates that are being evaluated, is
componenttext: Got it. And then secondly, just since there is this, the new buyback out there, and the bulk of it is coming at a point when leadership transition. And so if we think about kind of the search that's going on and the candidates that are being evaluated, is the board committed to finding someone who is entirely aligned with this current strategy? Is there a chance that someone will come in and we'll see a shift of strategy next year? Any comments around if there's a tie between the two right now?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, this is Richard. The board is very aligned as the leadership team is around this Value Creation Strategy. I wouldn't want to comment specifically, on what the next CEO would do, but I can tell you that our board members of spoken with investors have
componenttext: Mike, this is Richard. The board is very aligned as the leadership team is around this Value Creation Strategy. I wouldn't want to comment specifically, on what the next CEO would do, but I can tell you that our board members of spoken with investors have been very clear that they are committed to Value Creation. So that certainly will influence the next CEO's thinking around this. And it's been successful strategy for the company. So we are pleased with that.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Megan Magrath from MKM Partners.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Megan Magrath from MKM Partners.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of follow-ups. It sounds you're sort of reevaluating where we are in the cycle, and shifting your strategy a little bit. Curious if that has changed any of your specifics around your land buying strategy, at this stage in the cycle, do you place
componenttext: A couple of follow-ups. It sounds you're sort of reevaluating where we are in the cycle, and shifting your strategy a little bit. Curious if that has changed any of your specifics around your land buying strategy, at this stage in the cycle, do you place more emphasis on some of your risk factors in your model than others? Does your view on growth in the different segments of the market changed? How, not necessarily the amount of land that you're spending but how you might spend that land? Or do those risk factors and priority stay the same no matter where we are in the cycle?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Megan, this is Richard. I think I can help with that. We view everything we are announcing today as a continuation and perhaps an enhancement of what we've already been doing, which is shortening the overall length of position so we're taking on the land
componenttext: Megan, this is Richard. I think I can help with that. We view everything we are announcing today as a continuation and perhaps an enhancement of what we've already been doing, which is shortening the overall length of position so we're taking on the land side. We gave some good disclosure before that the last several years we've been buying much shorter position, so that continues. What we're also saying is that with 143,000 lots, we have a lot of dry powder to monetize from here, and that we don't need to grow our rate of land spend at 30% or 40% a year, as Bob indicated going forward. But the care with which we underwrite deals, the focus on closer to the city properties, the discipline to stay away from those tertiary BNC locations, the idea to not take on 10, 15 years worth of land risks on any one deal, that all stays the same going forward. And to be clear, we do think the markets got several years of growth ahead of it. We're just trying to be prudent with regard to recognizing the large land book that we have.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then just -- there had been some concern in recent weeks about perhaps the market slowing at the tail end of the quarter. Can you talk a little bit about cadence throughout the second quarter?
componenttext: And then just -- there had been some concern in recent weeks about perhaps the market slowing at the tail end of the quarter. Can you talk a little bit about cadence throughout the second quarter?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan. First few weeks of July have proven to be very similar to preview seasonal patterns that we see -- that we've seen in prior years. It's very normal. The cadence has proven out to be very normal seasonal type patterns.
componenttext: This is Ryan. First few weeks of July have proven to be very similar to preview seasonal patterns that we see -- that we've seen in prior years. It's very normal. The cadence has proven out to be very normal seasonal type patterns.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: I kind of want to maybe follow up on Megan's question, just a slightly different way. Going back to that recognition that the cycle is maturing and that maybe you're dialing back the land investments, you still have a fairly broad range of product categories. Does it think -- does it change how you think about the mix of the brands you have? Does it make you think -- would it make more sense to be a more streamlined builder on the move of categories or if you want to continue to have kind of a line in the water on all the different price segments right now?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Richard. Local operators are seeing with regard to demand in their business. And that's candidly fluid all the time. So as an example, if you operate in Southwest Florida, we're doing a lot of active adult business because that's the business ther
componenttext: This is Richard. Local operators are seeing with regard to demand in their business. And that's candidly fluid all the time. So as an example, if you operate in Southwest Florida, we're doing a lot of active adult business because that's the business there. Whereas in Texas the entry level is quite strong. So our local operations and what they're seeing will continue to that, that land seek its natural place of highest return. So we're not trying to make a macro call on the segment.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And just quickly as a follow up. headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 21, 2016
