componenttextpreview: Yes, Ivy, it's Ryan. I think the easiest way to look at it, frankly, is that discounts remained relatively flat with where they were in the prior quarter. We did not see a material change. As Bob mentioned in some of his comments, they're running right ar
componenttext: Yes, Ivy, it's Ryan. I think the easiest way to look at it, frankly, is that discounts remained relatively flat with where they were in the prior quarter. We did not see a material change. As Bob mentioned in some of his comments, they're running right around $10,000 a unit, which we think is very reasonable. Certainly, in some of the move-up price points, things have gotten to be a little bit more difficult. And we've seen accelerating demand on the first-time buyer, which I think, is reflective of some of the comments that I gave to you about where a lot of land investments went into third quarter.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. And Ivy, one of the things I'd add to that is as we look at the business and we don't necessarily look at it regionally or by segment the way you talked about it, but we've invested a fair much of money over the last couple of years, and we are focus
componenttext: Yes. And Ivy, one of the things I'd add to that is as we look at the business and we don't necessarily look at it regionally or by segment the way you talked about it, but we've invested a fair much of money over the last couple of years, and we are focused on getting return out of that investment. So our absorption paces, we were pleased with them. They were consistent with what we have seen over the last year or so, and the margins are still really strong on it. We're guiding down a little bit. To Ryan's point, it's a little bit harder to get price. Margin's a little bit harder to come by. But if these margins -- you'll see us continue to sell to actually realize the return on an investment. It's really important to remember it's not just margins, it's margin and pace, how quickly can we work through it. We've made good investments. We like the margins we're getting from them, and we like the return we could get if we could continue to sell against that. And so we're playing in the market. So you can see year-over-year we got a little bit of accrete in our discounts. that's almost community-by-community though. What's opened nearby, what are our competitors up to? But what we want to make sure we do is take all the money that we have invested and get the return out of it.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now bob, that's extremely helpful. So it's really a focus on return and getting that pace and getting your money back, basically, which is different than other builders. So I think it's important that people understand that strategy, and I appreciate the
componenttext: Now bob, that's extremely helpful. So it's really a focus on return and getting that pace and getting your money back, basically, which is different than other builders. So I think it's important that people understand that strategy, and I appreciate the follow-up on that.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Ivy, the only other thing that I'd add to your last comment there is that's really what's at the heart of the Value Creation strategy from the very beginning was it focused on return on investment.
componenttext: And Ivy, the only other thing that I'd add to your last comment there is that's really what's at the heart of the Value Creation strategy from the very beginning was it focused on return on investment.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Stephen East at Wells Fargo.
componenttext: We'll go next to Stephen East at Wells Fargo.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan, first of all, congratulations on the CEO role. And just could you expand a bit as you prepared -- in your prepared comments, you talked about the vision for the company, the operational changes, your land bank, et cetera. Could you give us maybe a l
componenttext: Ryan, first of all, congratulations on the CEO role. And just could you expand a bit as you prepared -- in your prepared comments, you talked about the vision for the company, the operational changes, your land bank, et cetera. Could you give us maybe a little bit more detail on how you're thinking about it? How long do maybe some of your plans take to implement, et cetera? Just the bigger things you've been grinding through since you've taken over?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Stephen. We haven't provided any details, and I probably wouldn't want to get into it today in terms of specifics around implementation. What I'll -- what I will elaborate on as I did in some of my prepared remarks is that I'm a very big supporter of
componenttext: Yes, Stephen. We haven't provided any details, and I probably wouldn't want to get into it today in terms of specifics around implementation. What I'll -- what I will elaborate on as I did in some of my prepared remarks is that I'm a very big supporter of our Value Creation strategy. The company has realized great financial benefits from that strategy. And we'll continue -- we're going to continue to run that playbook. My experiences in the operations of our organization over the last 15 years are certainly a little bit different and unique from Richard's, and you'll see heavy emphasis and focus from me as the leader of our organization on driving the efficiencies out of our homebuilding operations. That's where we made substantial and sizable gains over the last 4 or 5 years in becoming a more efficient builder. I believe that we can continue to drive that well into the future. The other piece that I talked about is just being more balanced in terms of where we're investing our land. We are brand agnostic, and we've talked about that quite a bit. We have an entry-level, first-time business today, and we'll continue to have that business well into the future with Centex, Pulte and Del Webb brand construct. I'm quite encouraged by the fact that we are becoming more balanced than what we've been, as represented by the 40% of our land acquisitions in the third quarter going to the first-time buyer.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And just a quick compound question, if you will. Bob, could you tell us the way you all define your terms? Tell us where you are now and maybe what type of longer-term targets you all had out there. And then as you look at buying back shares,
componenttext: Okay, great. And just a quick compound question, if you will. Bob, could you tell us the way you all define your terms? Tell us where you are now and maybe what type of longer-term targets you all had out there. And then as you look at buying back shares, I guess, a couple of quick -- a couple of mixed messages. You want to get to investment grade, but you've added significant debt. And with the equity trading at 1.5x booked, how do you reconcile that versus land opportunities, et cetera?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I guess, Stephen, first, to the second question, investment grade. What we've said is that we think we're behaving like an investment-grade credit. We have, over time. We have strong credit metrics that -- the offering that we did in July, I think,
componenttext: Well, I guess, Stephen, first, to the second question, investment grade. What we've said is that we think we're behaving like an investment-grade credit. We have, over time. We have strong credit metrics that -- the offering that we did in July, I think, are directly supportive of that view. What we've said is we won't jump through hoops to try and get somebody to say that we're investment grade. So I think, we're running a very, I think, disciplined and healthy capital structure. So -- and within that, we've laid out for the last couple of years what we're going to do with our capital, including to buyback shares. And I apologize, I forgot the first question.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: With the returns.
componenttext: With the returns.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Returns, sure. Well, if you look at our returns over the last couple of years, what they've been is relatively flat as we've grown the income statement, but we're growing our investment at the same time. Going forward, I think -- we've highlighted that we
componenttext: Returns, sure. Well, if you look at our returns over the last couple of years, what they've been is relatively flat as we've grown the income statement, but we're growing our investment at the same time. Going forward, I think -- we've highlighted that we would not be growing at the same rate in terms of investment. But that we can and do expect to be able to yield return off of the investments we're making, so I think you'll see improvement there. And what I think you can expect from us is, later this year, to lay out sort of what we think the target might be over time.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to John Lovallo at Bank of America.
componenttext: We'll go next to John Lovallo at Bank of America.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question would be, Bob, you guys laid out 20.5% to 21% gross margin, and you talked about SG&A as a percentage of sales at around 9%. I mean it would seem to imply that there's a decent chance that operating margin can be flattish to actually down n
componenttext: First question would be, Bob, you guys laid out 20.5% to 21% gross margin, and you talked about SG&A as a percentage of sales at around 9%. I mean it would seem to imply that there's a decent chance that operating margin can be flattish to actually down next year. I know you're not giving explicit guidance, but directionally, am I thinking about that correctly?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, I don't want to be piffy, but the math is the math. Again, we think the margins are strong. We think the operating margins will be strong. And what we're trying to do is manage, just like Ryan talked about, we're managing against return. It
componenttext: Well, I think, I don't want to be piffy, but the math is the math. Again, we think the margins are strong. We think the operating margins will be strong. And what we're trying to do is manage, just like Ryan talked about, we're managing against return. It's the total return of our income stream that's really important to us, and we certainly seek to maximize gross margin. We are trying to be as efficient as we possibly can, all with the goal towards driving strong operating margin. And again, not trying to be cute, that -- if you use 21% or 20.5% and 9%, that's still a strong relative operating margin compared to historical norms.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just thinking about kind of the cycle here. I mean, growth is arguably -- or the rate of growth, I should say, is arguably decelerating on an industry-wide basis. Your first-time community seemed like they won't be up and ru
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just thinking about kind of the cycle here. I mean, growth is arguably -- or the rate of growth, I should say, is arguably decelerating on an industry-wide basis. Your first-time community seemed like they won't be up and running until 2018. I guess, what is it that gives you confidence that the buyers are going to be there, and that the market is still going to hold in?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, I think, a couple of things here. Don't lose sight of the fact that we've got a very healthy first-time business today, and we have for a number of years. This isn't a new focus for us. We certainly are seeing additional opportunities as of late, an
componenttext: John, I think, a couple of things here. Don't lose sight of the fact that we've got a very healthy first-time business today, and we have for a number of years. This isn't a new focus for us. We certainly are seeing additional opportunities as of late, and we've allocated some incremental capital toward that space. And we'll continue to realize the benefits from the business that we've always had there, in addition to the more recent investments. So that would be the first piece of it. The other piece, in terms of kind of overall demand, we like where the housing market is quite a bit. When you look at overall new home sales this year, somewhere in the 575,000 to 600,000 range, we believe we're still under historical norms and historical equilibriums. And with an economy that is healthy and low interest rates, low supply, we see demand still being quite favorable, and we like how that shapes up for our business.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Stephen Kim with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: We'll go next to Stephen Kim with Evercore ISI.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Let me also say I really appreciate the detail you guys have given. And I agree with you also, Bob, about your operating market being pretty good where it is already. In that vein, I wanted to ask you for a little bit of clarity about your land spend. Fir
componenttext: Let me also say I really appreciate the detail you guys have given. And I agree with you also, Bob, about your operating market being pretty good where it is already. In that vein, I wanted to ask you for a little bit of clarity about your land spend. First of all, I don't think I got that development number, so if you could just give us the specific, what the land spend was in the quarter. And then with respect to this 40% on the spend that was on first-time buyers in the quarter, can you help us understand how much of this stuff is the land that you're buying? Is what you might consider a stereotypical -- stereotypically located in first-time community more sort of out in the outer fringe versus maybe some of the stuff that's a little closer in maybe different kind of first-time buyer community?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, Stephen, again, we got a couple of questions there. But LD in the quarter was $374 million, and total spend was $640 million when you add in the $266 million of land acquisition. So that brings us to -- for the year, to about $1.9 billion, and that
componenttext: Again, Stephen, again, we got a couple of questions there. But LD in the quarter was $374 million, and total spend was $640 million when you add in the $266 million of land acquisition. So that brings us to -- for the year, to about $1.9 billion, and that excludes Wieland. So pretty much right on track with the $1 billion to $1.2 billion that we have projected for the full year '15. And then for your question on that first-time buyer, yes, we've been pretty clear that we're not out in the exurbs, chasing volume in that space. So we're typically going to be a little bit closer in, we're typically going to be a little bit higher price point that more affluent, millennial, first-time buyers, a little bit older, partnered, might have 2 incomes. So I don't think we have changed at all what we had expressed that first-time business means to us. It's just that with the acceleration of that business, we're seeing more opportunities to invest. And so  of the approvals, and that's not necessarily cash flow, that's just approvals. So the cash will be spent at some point in the future [indiscernible] as we move in that first-time space.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. That's a helpful clarification. And then the second question I had, related to your gross margin commentary, obviously, a lot of things embedded in your outlook for 2017. I'm sure, some of the other folks have touched on some of those. I wan
componenttext: Got it. Okay. That's a helpful clarification. And then the second question I had, related to your gross margin commentary, obviously, a lot of things embedded in your outlook for 2017. I'm sure, some of the other folks have touched on some of those. I wanted to see if you could comment a little bit more specifically, on 2, however. One, is what you're seeing in lumber. We've seen the Random Lengths have moved up pretty noticeably here. I was wondering if that's factored into your thinking? Also the Fair Labor Standards Act seems to have the potential to raise labor costs for sort of lesser-skilled laborers who have to put in more than 40 hours in a given week. And you had alluded to Hurricane Matthew possible delays, is any of that embedded in your outlook in 4Q '16?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, yes, Stephen, for the fourth quarter and even for next year, it is our best estimate today. And so yes, it encompasses everything we know. I think, the reality is that Matthew is more likely a production and cost issue. Time will tell about on the l
componenttext: Well, yes, Stephen, for the fourth quarter and even for next year, it is our best estimate today. And so yes, it encompasses everything we know. I think, the reality is that Matthew is more likely a production and cost issue. Time will tell about on the labor side. But the folks that are working on the powerlines aren't the folks that are building our building homes, so it's not an absolutely labor issue. It's just will we be able get power turned on?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And Stephen, the other thing that I'd -- this is Ryan. The other thing that I'd mention about Hurricane Matthew, we actually -- we feel quite fortunate that there wasn't a huge human effect or human damage as a result of storm. Our employees are safe. The
componenttext: And Stephen, the other thing that I'd -- this is Ryan. The other thing that I'd mention about Hurricane Matthew, we actually -- we feel quite fortunate that there wasn't a huge human effect or human damage as a result of storm. Our employees are safe. The majority of the residents that live in the affected areas came through the storm safely. Our properties, in particular, fared quite well. We had minimal damage. It's mostly some landscape-type cleanup that we're going to be dealing with. Bob mentioned the power companies. There's a lot of work that they've got to do to restore the existing infrastructure. And what we'll see it likely happen based on past experience, and I lived in Florida for a long time. I'm quite familiar with what happens post-hurricane storms. As they rebuild infrastructure, new meter sets and getting new communities energized will take last priority. We do believe that we've factored the best information into our Q4 estimates that we can. But as you can certainly appreciate, we don't have total visibility into what the backlog is for the power companies.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Susan Maklari with UBS.
componenttext: We'll go next to Susan Maklari with UBS.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: As first of, you talked about the long term trends in terms of SG&A and getting to that targeted 9% level next year, but it seems like you also made a bit of progress this quarter around to where we were, can you just talk a little bit about the benefit m
componenttext: As first of, you talked about the long term trends in terms of SG&A and getting to that targeted 9% level next year, but it seems like you also made a bit of progress this quarter around to where we were, can you just talk a little bit about the benefit maybe that you're already starting to see from some of the changes that you've made?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Susan. This is Ryan. At the end of our Q2 call, we talked about -- we've got a targeted run rate of 10% in 2016. We were going to reduce that by 100% or 100 basis points going to a targeted run rate of 9% in 2017 and any of the actions that we plan t
componenttext: Yes, Susan. This is Ryan. At the end of our Q2 call, we talked about -- we've got a targeted run rate of 10% in 2016. We were going to reduce that by 100% or 100 basis points going to a targeted run rate of 9% in 2017 and any of the actions that we plan to take toward that target would be taken in the third quarter. Bob laid out some of the details of how we've affected that and how we've effectuated that rather. We were already seeing the benefits of that and we feel very much on track towards that target of 9% for 2017. But to be -- put a finer point on it, yes, we are already benefiting from the actions we've taken.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then perhaps slightly bigger picture. Recognizing that this is perhaps a -- or is a very different election cycle than what we've seen historically. Can you talk a little bit to any impact that, that has on consumer psyche or demand as we get cl
componenttext: Okay. And then perhaps slightly bigger picture. Recognizing that this is perhaps a -- or is a very different election cycle than what we've seen historically. Can you talk a little bit to any impact that, that has on consumer psyche or demand as we get closer to the election? And perhaps maybe the DC market specifically, but even just broader thoughts?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Susan. My experience from spending a number of years in the field in our operations is any time we're this close to the end of an election cycle, I think the general public is trying to calculate and figure out what the impact will be of a change in
componenttext: Yes, Susan. My experience from spending a number of years in the field in our operations is any time we're this close to the end of an election cycle, I think the general public is trying to calculate and figure out what the impact will be of a change in power, moving from one side of the political power grid to the other. What that will do to their earning power potential, what that will do to job growth, what that will do to the stock market, et cetera. My general sense is that folks may be pause and wait and see. We actually, as you saw from our sign-up growth and our absorption paces, we are quite happy, very happy in fact, with what we saw in the third quarter. So I don't know that we saw any kind of noticeable impacts. I think I'd probably speak for the collective country in saying I think it will be nice once this election cycle is over in a few short weeks.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll take our next question from Megan McGrath at MKM Partners.
componenttext: We'll take our next question from Megan McGrath at MKM Partners.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess my first question is sort of a chicken versus egg question. You mentioned a little bit in one of your answers before about being generally product-agnostic, although it certainly -- although you talked about going to 40%, and it sounds like you're
componenttext: I guess my first question is sort of a chicken versus egg question. You mentioned a little bit in one of your answers before about being generally product-agnostic, although it certainly -- although you talked about going to 40%, and it sounds like you're, Ryan, excited about that. So I guess, are you starting to talk about getting more diversified because you saw that your underwriting was pushing these first-time buyers? Or was there something proactive you did in your underwriting to shift towards the first-time buyer in the last couple of months?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Susan (sic) [ Megan ]. The way that I would answer that is we don't necessarily want to be over-indexed toward any one specific buyer. I think what you've heard in my prepared remarks is that we'd like to run a balanced business. We feel that we have
componenttext: Yes, Susan (sic) [ Megan ]. The way that I would answer that is we don't necessarily want to be over-indexed toward any one specific buyer. I think what you've heard in my prepared remarks is that we'd like to run a balanced business. We feel that we have that today. We'd like to continue to ensure that we have it. And what you'll see over time is that as there are other opportunities with a particular buyer group, you may see our spend flex ever so slightly toward that particular buyer group. And as we've seen a recovery with that first-time buyer, paces have been accelerating, I think that you've seen us spend a little bit more money toward that opportunity. On the whole, though, when we look at the entire enterprise, that goal is going to be maintain balance.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you didn't really shift anything in your underwriting criteria in the quarter to purposely go after more first-time buyers?
componenttext: So you didn't really shift anything in your underwriting criteria in the quarter to purposely go after more first-time buyers?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we did not. Our underwriting criteria has stayed the same.
componenttext: No, we did not. Our underwriting criteria has stayed the same.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And just a quick follow-up on the SG&A. Are you done with the bulk of the low-hanging fruit there? Or there -- is there some more to come?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And just a quick follow-up on the SG&A. Are you done with the bulk of the low-hanging fruit there? Or there -- is there some more to come?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're done. We'll always work to be as efficient as we possibly can. But all of the actions that we plan to take, we have taken, and we're done.
componenttext: We're done. We'll always work to be as efficient as we possibly can. But all of the actions that we plan to take, we have taken, and we're done.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Jack Micenko at SIG.
componenttext: We'll go next to Jack Micenko at SIG.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bob, I wanted to talk about the G&A number versus the percentage. You took about 350 FTEs out of the mix. You did a 183 number. So I back up the 12 and onetime items, we're back to sort of, like, 165 kind of number. I think in the past, you've talked abou
componenttext: Bob, I wanted to talk about the G&A number versus the percentage. You took about 350 FTEs out of the mix. You did a 183 number. So I back up the 12 and onetime items, we're back to sort of, like, 165 kind of number. I think in the past, you've talked about a 161, 165 run rate, I guess the question is does that number come down from here going forward? Or how do we think about the dollar level of G&A?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jack, there is variability based on volume, right? And so I don't want to start hanging targets on dollar levels. What we've indicated is 9% of revenues for next year. We'll be -- our projection is 10% for this year. We think we'll get there. So rath
componenttext: Yes, Jack, there is variability based on volume, right? And so I don't want to start hanging targets on dollar levels. What we've indicated is 9% of revenues for next year. We'll be -- our projection is 10% for this year. We think we'll get there. So rather than turning it into an x dollars per quarter, because there are -- while many of our costs are relatively fixed over time, sales commissions aren't in SG&A, there are model and start-up costs that come through the SG&A line in connection with opening new communities. And so it really does flex, and I don't want to put unrealistic or bad targets out. So the 9% is where we'd like you to think about it.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in the financial services business, the capture rate looks kind of in line, but it looks like you did a much better margin there. Is there anything different about the mortgage business over the last quarter that would have driven that?
componenttext: Okay. And then in the financial services business, the capture rate looks kind of in line, but it looks like you did a much better margin there. Is there anything different about the mortgage business over the last quarter that would have driven that?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. It's -- I mean, candidly, it's mostly volume-driven. We are operating in an environment where we have pretty strong margins today. And have, with little fits and starts over the last few years, they're operating in a pretty strong margin environment.
componenttext: No. It's -- I mean, candidly, it's mostly volume-driven. We are operating in an environment where we have pretty strong margins today. And have, with little fits and starts over the last few years, they're operating in a pretty strong margin environment. Our team does a great job to take half it's lenders, so they're working with our customers. We seek to be competitive on price. And so we're out there kind of battling against all the other originators. They do a fantastic job, and the margin environment has been pretty good.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll go next to Buck Horne at Raymond James.
componenttext: We'll go next to Buck Horne at Raymond James.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: A little bit of color on the geographic mix of where you're making new land investments right now in terms of just where you thinking you'd want to allocate more dollars regionally or by state?
componenttext: A little bit of color on the geographic mix of where you're making new land investments right now in terms of just where you thinking you'd want to allocate more dollars regionally or by state?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's Bob. We go through a process annually that we update candidly quarterly, where we look at the capital allocation, and we give our field teams 3 years of visibility in terms of what their expectation can be for capital availability. And candidly,
componenttext: Yes, it's Bob. We go through a process annually that we update candidly quarterly, where we look at the capital allocation, and we give our field teams 3 years of visibility in terms of what their expectation can be for capital availability. And candidly, we're a buyer everywhere. We certainly look to demand and demographic considerations when we think about it. We think about the team's historical ability to get money invested where they're indexed, so to Ryan's point about balanced business. Obviously, if you look at Texas and Dallas, in particular, we've committed a lot of capital there because the market is so strong. But on the whole, there are no markets where we're saying, "You don't get capital." And there's none where we said you're getting twice as much as you used to.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful.  And I'm curious about John Wieland as well. Just maybe how you would evaluate that segment's performance so far? And maybe you gave this earlier. I'm curious about what the change in the move-up segment absorption pace was without the eff
componenttext: That's helpful.  And I'm curious about John Wieland as well. Just maybe how you would evaluate that segment's performance so far? And maybe you gave this earlier. I'm curious about what the change in the move-up segment absorption pace was without the effect of Wieland?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Buck. It's Ryan. And I would tell you, thus far, we're very pleased with the John Wieland acquisition and the related integration efforts. Our team, frankly, has done a phenomenal job in bringing the Wieland platform onto our platform, and we're quit
componenttext: Yes, Buck. It's Ryan. And I would tell you, thus far, we're very pleased with the John Wieland acquisition and the related integration efforts. Our team, frankly, has done a phenomenal job in bringing the Wieland platform onto our platform, and we're quite happy with the results that we're getting there and it's in line with our underwriting criteria. One of the things that we really look, with that particular acquisition, was margin opportunity by becoming more efficient on the cost side, and we're continuing to work through that. When -- as to your absorption comment ex Wieland, our move-up absorptions were flat.

componenttextpreview: Well, Will, I'd probably just want to clarify the comment. We're -- the focus is on running a balanced business, and we're not going to get over-indexed toward any one particular buyer group. We like the recovery that we're seeing in the first-time buyer.
componenttext: Well, Will, I'd probably just want to clarify the comment. We're -- the focus is on running a balanced business, and we're not going to get over-indexed toward any one particular buyer group. We like the recovery that we're seeing in the first-time buyer. They were noticeably absent in this recovery. This recovery was predominantly led by the move-up buyer. And I think as the economy, and frankly, the housing recovery cycle has continued to progress, we're seeing strength from the first-time buyers, and thus, additional opportunities for us to put capital to work. As Bob highlighted and detailed, our strategy has been to stay closer to the job core, closer to the city center. We're not going into the exurbs and chasing volume for volume's sake. So while we like what we're seeing and we're seeing opportunities to be a little bit more balanced in how we're allocating capital, you won't see us become over-indexed toward any one buyer group.

componenttextpreview: Yes, Alex. This is Ryan. We're not just as -- we're not investing at the same rate that we were previously in the active adult spaces. You're also seeing the overall size of the communities come down and be a little bit smaller. If you look at -- if you l
componenttext: Yes, Alex. This is Ryan. We're not just as -- we're not investing at the same rate that we were previously in the active adult spaces. You're also seeing the overall size of the communities come down and be a little bit smaller. If you look at -- if you look historically, some of our Del Webb communities were 2,000 and 3,000 and 4,000 homes per community, and that's simply gotten smaller over time. So that would be the primary driver of bring the average years of supply down. They're just simply smaller communities. We're very big believers in the active adult space. It's a huge consumer group. We have an unbelievably strong brand with the Del Webb, and we're going to continue to play in that space with that particular consumer.

At this time, I'd like to turn the conference over to Jim Zeumer. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Audra, and good morning to everyone participating in today's call. I want to welcome you to PulteGroup's conference call to discuss our third quarter financial results for the 3 months ended September 30, 2016.Joining me for today's call are
componenttext:
Thank you, Audra, and good morning to everyone participating in today's call. I want to welcome you to PulteGroup's conference call to discuss our third quarter financial results for the 3 months ended September 30, 2016.
Joining me for today's call are Ryan Marshall, President and CEO; Bob O'shaughnessy, Executive Vice President, CFO; Jim Ossowski, Vice President, Finance and Controller.
A copy of this morning's earnings release and the presentation slides that accompany today's call have been posted to our corporate website at pultegroupinc.com. We will also post an audio replay of today's call to our website a little later today. 
Before we begin the discussion, I want to alert all the participants that today's presentation may include forward-looking statements about PulteGroup's future performance. Actual results could differ materially from those suggested by our comments made today. The most significant risk factors that could affect future results are summarized as part of today's earnings release and within the accompanying presentation slides. These risk factors and other key information are detailed in our SEC filings, including our annual and quarterly reports.
Now let me turn the call over to Ryan Marshall. Ryan?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. As this morning press release detailed, our Q3 results showed the company delivered another quarter of double-digit growth on both the top and bottom lines. And consistent with positive demand trends in U.S. housing, we realized one of our la
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. As this morning press release detailed, our Q3 results showed the company delivered another quarter of double-digit growth on both the top and bottom lines. And consistent with positive demand trends in U.S. housing, we realized one of our largest increases in sign-ups in recent years, up 17% in units and 25% in dollar value, as our business continues to benefit from the increased land investments we made in recent years.
Particularly encouraging is that we realized higher sales across all buyer groups, which is a great sign on the overall health of the market. Along with showing strong demand on the front end, we realized a 16% increase in deliveries for the quarter, which drove a 29% gain in top line revenues to $1.9 billion. The top line growth in business carried through to the bottom line as the company generated a significant expansion in earnings for the third quarter.
Overall, I am very pleased with the company's very strong third quarter. Before I turn over the call, however, there are a few other thoughts I'd like to offer before we get into discussing our operating results.
Since being named CEO in September, I've had the opportunity to speak with a number of shareholders, including meeting more than 60 investors during my attendance at one of the industry's larger home building conferences several weeks ago.
These conversations gave me the chance to exchange questions and comments with investors about PulteGroup, our strategy, about management and board changes, and most importantly, about the fundamentals of the housing market.
The conversations were wide-ranging. There were, however, a handful of questions which routinely came up regarding how we plan to run the business and what, if any changes, we plan to make. Given the consistent level of investor interest, I thought it appropriate to share a few of my answers with this larger group.
First, I've been with the PulteGroup for more than 15 years. Most of that time was spent in our operations, running some of our largest businesses, and more recently, as a senior officer, managing many of our corporate staff functions. In other words, I've been deeply involved in and worked closely with Richard on the development and implementation of the company's Value Creation strategy.
I've seen firsthand the significant operating and financial benefits we've realized from direct Value Creation since its launch over 5 years ago. I certainly remain an advocate of Value Creation and plan to continue operating against this strategy going forward.
That being said, I think it's appropriate to state that my background and my career experiences are unique and different from Richard's. So over time, you could see us emphasize certain things more strongly than we have in the past.
For example, having spent most of my career in the operations, I can tell you that operations is an area of particular focus, even passion for me. I am and will continue investing a lot of my time with my staff and our field leaders on finding opportunities to drive greater construction efficiencies and squeeze additional costs from our building processes. Programs such as Common Plan Management, value engineering and strategic pricing have been very successful, and we'll be working hard to build on these programs going forward.
Over the last 5 years, we have raised PulteGroup's gross margins to be arguably the best in the industry, and we certainly want to keep it that way.
Beyond the operations, we've also made progress adjusting our land portfolio to match our Value Creation goals of generating higher returns while managing our risk. I believe, however, there is more for us to accomplish.
For example, based on our trailing 12 months of deliveries, we own approximately 5.2 years of lots, which is down from 7.7 years in 2011. Over time, I would like to see this number continue to move lower, and ultimately get below 4 years, even approaching 3 years of ownership.
While this will take years to accomplish, there are actions we have implemented, which should allow our own land position to decline gradually over time. First, we are focusing our investments on shorter, faster-turning communities. Second, we are working through our larger legacy web positions, which will allow us to reduce to 7.4 years of active adult lots we own today. And third, we are well-positioned to continue to grow our unit volume, which effectively reduces our years of own supply.
By focusing on shortening the duration of our land assets, we can accelerate inventory turns, improve returns on invested capital and reduce some of the risks inherent in the business. This will take time to accomplish, but I wanted you to understand the long-term direction for the company. 
And finally, also relating to our investment practices, I think the potential exists for us to be a little more balanced in our market position. We've clearly capitalized on the strong demand within the move-up category, but I see opportunities for us to realize a better balance across the buyer groups we serve. Today, approximately 45% of our deliveries are to move-up buyers, but at the division level, this percentage can be higher. 
Going forward, I believe we can diversify and expand our business among first-time buyers, where market demand appears to be accelerating. We will seek to replicate the success certain PulteGroup markets have achieved by building our first-time business in more markets across the country. 
On this front, I would note that approximately 40% of our land approvals in the third quarter were for first-time buyer communities, which is higher than recent quarters. 
Obviously, these are very high-level thoughts, but I wanted to provide some insights into how I view the business.
Now let me turn the call over to Bob for a review of the quarter.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Ryan, and good morning, everybody. As we've discussed on recent calls, 2016 reflects the growth we've expected, given our increasing land spend over the last several years. Q3 clearly continues that trend as home sale revenues grew by 29% to $1.
componenttext:
Thanks, Ryan, and good morning, everybody. As we've discussed on recent calls, 2016 reflects the growth we've expected, given our increasing land spend over the last several years. 
Q3 clearly continues that trend as home sale revenues grew by 29% to $1.9 billion, driven by a 16% increase in closings to 5,037 homes, combined with an 11% or $37,000 increase in average selling price to $374,000.
Consistent with our prior guidance, our deliveries of 5,037 homes represented a conversion rate of 52% in the quarter, which represents a roughly 400 basis point improvement over the third quarter of  last year. Our conversion rates have improved, but labor resources in many markets remained stressed and will likely continue to be so during this housing recovery.
Based on feedback from our division presidents, it's clear that labor availability has gotten even tighter relative to last year and continues to impact production timelines. Our decision last year to put a few more spec homes into production has turned out to be the right one, given these market dynamics.
Looking at the fourth quarter, we currently project our conversion rate to be in the range between 62% and 64%. This represents the meaningful increase over the third quarter and is comparable with the fourth quarter of last year. We're pleased with the improvements we've made to our production cadence, especially in light of the challenging trade environment.
One item to note, however, is the potential impact of Hurricane Matthew on our operations. We are fortunate that none of our employees were injured, and our communities weathered the storm extremely well, so our recovery time should be quick. This is likely not true for the local power companies, which had a lot of work in front of them restoring power and rebuilding infrastructure.
As that activity will take priority over installing meters or even bringing power to our new subdivisions, it's possible that we may face production and delivery delays in affected areas.
Looking at our closings by buyer group during the quarter, 29% were first-time; 44% were move-up; and 27% were active adult. In the comparable prior year period, the breakdown was 33% first-time; 35% move-up; and 32% active adult. The 11% gain in average sales prices for the quarter reflects the higher percentage of move-up closings as well as higher prices realized in each buyer group. In fact, our average sales price has increased 8% to $283,000 among our first-time buyers; 11% to $441,000 among our move-up buyers; and 4% to $358,000 among our active adult buyers.
With our backlog ASP showing an increase of 11% to $393,000 compared to last year, which is also up 5% from our Q3 deliveries, we expect our average selling prices to continue moving gradually higher in the coming quarters.
The company's recorded gross margin for Q3 was 21.1%, which was 10 basis points below our guidance range. Beyond margin pressure from higher absolute land cost is recycled through our land pipeline. We continued to experience labor rate inflation as it relates to both land development and house construction costs.
We had anticipated house costs to rise 1.5% to 2% this year, but labor costs are running outside of that band in many of our markets.
While we expected cost to rise at this stage of the housing cycle, market dynamics are not allowing these costs to be passed through to [indiscernible] home buyers at the same rates we experienced over the past 2 years.
Assuming these conditions continue in Q4 and into 2017, we now expect Q4 margins to be in the range of 20.5% to 21%. Further, we expect this range will likely carry through to the full year 2017. As is our practice, we'll update you as the year progresses.
While our margin trends has been lower, I think it's important to highlight that we're still generating the highest margins among the big builders. As a reminder, our convention is to include sales commissions and cost of sales, while most of the industry reports commissions and SG&A. As a result, on a comparative basis, our reported gross margin present lower than our peers. On average, our commissions are approximately 350 basis points of revenue, so on a comparable basis, our reported Q3 gross margin of 21.1% would equate to 24.6%.
We believe part of the reason for our strong relative margins is our strategy to maximize the amount of lot premiums and not having to use [indiscernible] to increase the amount of our highest margin revenue streams.
In the third quarter, our total option revenues and lot premiums increased 9% over last year to approximately $71,000 per closing.
Sales discounts in the third quarter were 2.7% of sales, which is flat with Q2 this year and up about 70 basis points from last year,  where the roughly $10,000 per home certainly remained modest.
SG&A expenses in the third quarter was $183 million or 9.7% of home sale revenues.  Included in this total are $8 billion of severance cost associated with actions taken in the quarter to reduce overhead expenses.
Among the actions we took was a reduction in our work force of approximately 350 people. The majority of those reductions took place in our corporate or area structures. Many of those roles has been established at the outset of our Value Creation efforts, but could be cut back us related initiatives are now part of standard operating procedures. In implementing these actions, we were obviously very careful to ensure we didn't hinder the ability of our field operations to manage what we expect to be a growing volume business in 2017 and beyond.
Also included in this quarter's SG&A were approximately $4 million of costs with shareholders activities. Having successfully reached agreements to 2 of our larger shareholders, we expect these costs to drop materially going forward.
As a reminder, on our last call, we discussed plans to cut SG&A cost from the expected 10% of revenues in 2016 to a target of 9% in 2017. All significant activity related to the actions to achieve our targeted spend level in 2017 were completed during the quarter.
Last year's third quarter SG&A spend of $159 million or 10.9% of revenues included a $6 million benefit associated with the reserve adjustment taken in the period.
In the third quarter of this year, we also reported $20 million of charges within other expenses net. This includes a $15 million charge due to the settlement of a dispute over a land transaction that we terminated a decade ago with the collapse of the housing market, in addition to $5 million of lease exit and related costs taken in connection with our SG&A reduction efforts.
Financial services, during the quarter, generated pretax income of $21 million, up from $14 million last year as it benefited primarily from higher construction volumes in our homebuilding operations.
Mortgage capture rate for the quarter was 81% compared to 83% last year. Our tax rate in the quarter was 39.5%, which compares to our prior guidance of 38%. The increase related to adjustments to our deferred tax assets resulting from changes in certain state tax rates, which impacted our reported earnings by $0.01 per share.
Reported net income for the quarter was $128 million or $0.37 per share, which includes $31 million of pretax charges I detailed. That reduced our reported earnings per share by $0.06 per share.
Earnings per share for the quarter was calculated using approximately 342 million shares outstanding, which is down 3% from last year, resulting largely from share repurchase activities.
Looking at our homebuilding operations, we had 9,235 homes under construction at the end of the third quarter, which is up 18% over last year. Consistent with our strategy to increase specs but at a controlled rate, specs were 24% of Q3 homes under construction, which is up from 17% in Q3 of last year but effectively flat on a sequential basis from the second quarter of this year. We ended the quarter with 600 finished specs or less than 1 per community, which is up only slightly from the second quarter of this year.
We recorded 4,775 sign-ups during the third quarter, which represents an increase of 17% over the prior year. On a dollar basis, sign-ups increased an even greater 25% to $1.8 billion.
Looking at our sign-ups by buyer group. First time increased 8%, move-up increased 30% and active adult increased 9%. Adjusting for changes in community count, our absorption pace has increased 4% for the first-time buyers and 14% among active adult buyers, but were lower by 4% among move-up buyers. Beyond the impact from our Wieland communities, which has slow absorption paces given their higher prices, some divisions have noted move-up buyers are taking longer to sign contracts. 
During the third quarter, we operated from 709 committees, which is up 16% over last year. The year-over-year increase is consistent with prior guidance for community count growth over the prior year in the range of 10% to 15%.
We remain active in the land acquisition arena. During the third quarter, we approved approximately 3,100 lots for purchase. At the end of the September, we owned approximately 102,000 lots and controlled an additional 43,000 lots via option. In total, we spent $266 million on land acquisition during the quarter, which brings our 9-month spend to approximately $910 million, excluding our purchase of the Wieland assets.
During the quarter, we also repurchased 12 million of our shares, representing just over 3% of our outstanding float for $250 million or $20.77 per share. This brings our total repurchase activity during 2016 to approximately 18 million shares for $350 million.
As we discussed on our Q2 call, we plan to continue to return excess funds to shareholders, subject to market conditions, through the repurchase of an additional $250 million of shares in Q4 and $1 billion in 2017.
In July, we raised $1 billion of 5- and 10-year debt at very attractive rates. Proceeds from the transaction were used to repay approximately $500 million of outstanding debt as well as to help fund our operations and our share repurchase activities. 
We ended the quarter with a debt to cap ratio of 40%, which is within the 30% to 40% range we seek to operate in. Depending upon the timing of future share repurchases, we may move above 40%, but expected future earnings should work to quickly delever our overall capital structure.
We ended the quarter with $461 million of cash, which resulted in a net debt to cap ratio of 36%.
Now let me turn the call over to Ryan for some comments on market conditions. Ryan?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bob. While there can be conflicting signals from period-to-period across the variety of metrics people track, I think most feel that economic conditions are improving, albeit at a slower pace than most would like.Recent moves higher by 10-year t
componenttext:
Thanks, Bob. While there can be conflicting signals from period-to-period across the variety of metrics people track, I think most feel that economic conditions are improving, albeit at a slower pace than most would like.
Recent moves higher by 10-year treasury rates further suggest that the economy continues to get stronger. Certainly, the sizable gains seen in recent U.S. new home sales data supports the position that housing remains on a sustained path of recovery. As has been the case for the past several years, demand is being aided by low unemployment, job formations, a low interest rate environment and generally favorable supply dynamics.
With a 17% increase in units and a 25% increase in dollars, PulteGroup's third quarter sign-up data tracks to move higher in the broader housing market, and the anecdotal comments from our field reinforced the view that while there can be volatility from point-to-point, the overall trend is for modestly higher volume. 
For example, looking at the demand conditions in the quarter on a regional basis, we saw the following: strong demand in Florida and much of the Southeast, although Charlotte and Raleigh were a little bit choppy during the quarter at some of the higher price points. We didn't see much change in the Mid-Atlantic and Northeast markets, where we're having to compete for each new sign-up. We have our eyes opened for any possible acceleration in D.C. once we get through the election cycle. Our Midwest and Texas operations continue to see strong demand conditions across the markets and throughout the quarter. As we said before, Houston has held up much better than expected, and given the recent rise in oil prices, it could be that the worst has already passed. Finally, in the Western 1/3 of the country, demand was solid throughout the quarter as we continued to experience good sign-up paces in our major markets of Phoenix, Las Vegas and Northern and Southern California.
Through the first few weeks of October, demand appears to be on its normal seasonal track. 
Overall, we are very pleased with Q3, and more broadly, the first 9 months of the year as we were able to get new communities opened, and they were met with strong buyer interest. With over 9,400 homes in backlog, we are well-positioned to complete a very strong 2016.
Let me close by saying it's a positive to have reached a resolution with 2 of our major shareholders and to have removed any uncertainties related to company leadership as we've successfully completed our announced CEO transition. Now we can focus conversations on talking about the business. As you read this morning and you heard in our comments, there are a lot of positives to discuss. 
And finally, I want to say thank you to the employees of PulteGroup. You've done an amazing job staying focused on serving our customers and delivering great quality homes. 
Now let me turn the call back to Jim Zeumer. Jim?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first from Nishu Sood at Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] We'll take our first from Nishu Sood at Deutsche Bank.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Tim Daley on for Nishu. So my first question is regarding kind of the absorption pace that you guys saw this quarter. So there's a bit of concern out there that pushing volumes be up absorptions rather than community count could accelerat
componenttext: This is actually Tim Daley on for Nishu. So my first question is regarding kind of the absorption pace that you guys saw this quarter. So there's a bit of concern out there that pushing volumes be up absorptions rather than community count could accelerate some gross margin slippage. But that didn't seem to be the case this quarter with most of the order growth coming from community count. So obviously, you said the gross margin a bit of the pressure mainly came from indiscernible]. But as you move forward, do you have the communities and the pipeline ready to go? Or do you expect some gains to come from absorptions going forward?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Tim, I think if you're asking about over the next 12 to 18 months, certainly, we own all the land that we have. We've got production slated for both land development and opening of communities. So I think what you've seen, at least in our quarter, i
componenttext: Well, Tim, I think if you're asking about over the next 12 to 18 months, certainly, we own all the land that we have. We've got production slated for both land development and opening of communities. So I think what you've seen, at least in our quarter, is that absorptions held pretty firm. They were up 4% in the first-time's pace. Ours were down 3% in the move-up, which includes Wieland and a little bit of stickiness. And nice pace in the active adult's pace, being up 14%, 15%. So the market -- there's some supply out there. So I think, at the end of the day, I can't speak to what others are going to do, but I think you can expect to see the same from us, trying to realize return. We're going to keep selling the communities.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, this is Ryan, the other  thing that I would just point out on the community count guidance, we had provided guidance in the back half of the year to show 10% to 15% growth year-over-year. And as you can see from our reported quarter, in the third qua
componenttext: Tim, this is Ryan, the other  thing that I would just point out on the community count guidance, we had provided guidance in the back half of the year to show 10% to 15% growth year-over-year. And as you can see from our reported quarter, in the third quarter, we reported 16% growth year-over-year, which demonstrates that we've gotten our new communities opened.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just to follow up quickly. So you've touched on the 40% of land approvals in 3Q being the first time versus, I think, you've mentioned about 29% of closings for 3Q? So with this low -- the shorter land profile that you guys have on the investment, wer
componenttext: And just to follow up quickly. So you've touched on the 40% of land approvals in 3Q being the first time versus, I think, you've mentioned about 29% of closings for 3Q? So with this low -- the shorter land profile that you guys have on the investment, were these kind of similar to the 2- to 3-year investment kind of horizon that you've been talking about recently? And how does that gross margin compare? And when should it mix in?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Tim, this is Ryan. It does fall, in terms of the tenure of land, the averages that we've been running has been shy of 3 years with recent approvals, and this quarter is consistent with that.
componenttext: Tim, this is Ryan. It does fall, in terms of the tenure of land, the averages that we've been running has been shy of 3 years with recent approvals, and this quarter is consistent with that.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Like everything else, Tim, we don't underwrite to margin, we underwrite to return. And so every one of them is sort of unique, how many of them are optioned, how many of them are raw with development work. But we haven't seen a significant change act
componenttext: Yes. Like everything else, Tim, we don't underwrite to margin, we underwrite to return. And so every one of them is sort of unique, how many of them are optioned, how many of them are raw with development work. But we haven't seen a significant change actually in the margins that we're seeing in the underwriting process.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: First question I had was on -- also around the first time and the margins, and Ryan, some of your comments regarding kind of recognizing some of the stronger demands seen for that segment. I'm just trying to get a sense of what you're on track to do in terms of first-time percent of deliveries for '16 and if the '17 guidance bakes in any kind of incremental exposure as maybe you do a soft shift increasing towards that segment?

componenttext: Mike, it's Ryan. I'll take the first piece of that, and I'll have Bob to give you a few more comments. But in terms of our first -- or the acquisitions that we've made that are targeted towards the first-time buyer, there won't be any impact on our 2017 margins.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, exactly. So if we're putting land under contract today, it's going to be '18 production and beyond. So in terms of mix shift, you won't see anything until then.
componenttext: Yes, exactly. So if we're putting land under contract today, it's going to be '18 production and beyond. So in terms of mix shift, you won't see anything until then.

componenttext: And Mike, the only other thing that I'd add to that is I'd reiterate what Bob's comment was a minute ago, we don't underwrite the margins. We underwrite the return. Margin is certainly an important component of the equation, but it's not the only thing that we look at.

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016

componenttext: All right, that's helpful. And it's good to clarify because, obviously, sometimes the first-time parcels are faster-turning and kind of get into the system a little quicker. How should we think about 2017 in terms of, obviously, you what you have in the pipeline and kind of your plans. Should we expect a similar type of 10% to 15% rate? Or -- and perhaps like some of your peers, slowing down a little bit to high single digits?

headline: PulteGroup, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 20, 2016
